editionStmt.edition: This early release includes some 500 EEBO-TCP transcriptions of Early Modern plays that have undergone several routines to create an interoperable and algorithmically amenable corpus of Early Modern Drama. Many incompletely or incorrectly transcribed words have been corrected, including obvious printers' errors, but the text has not been proofread word by word. Each word in the text has been identified as a distinct token with its own xml:id and assigned to a lemma, a part of speech, and a standard spelling. Speech prefixes were mapped to unique speaker ID's as "who" attributes of sp elements. elements

respStmt.resp: Incompletely or incorrectly transcribed words were reviewed and in many cases fixed by
respStmt.name: Melina Yeh

respStmt.resp: Tokenization and linguistic annotation using MorphAdorner and NUPOS 2.0 were provided by
respStmt.name: Philip R. Burns

respStmt.resp: With the help of Thomas L. Berger's Index of Characters in Early Modern English Drama Printed Plays, 1500-1660 speech prefixes were mapped to unique "who" attributes of sp elements by
respStmt.name: Martin Mueller

respStmt.resp: A provisional, rudimentry, and algorithmically produced castlist was added as a new div in the back listing each role with their number of speeches sorted from high to low by
respStmt.name: Martin Mueller

respStmt.name: Martin Mueller

note.p: A dramatization of William Painter's "Palace of pleasure", tome 2, which is a translation of Matteo Bandello's "Ariabarzane senescalco del re di Persia" from his "Novelle" (part 1, novella 2).
F4 cancellans recto catchword: "That". Variant: with cancellandum F4; recto catchword: "His".

div.p: The royal King, and the loyal subject.
As it hath been acted with great applause by the Queen's majesty's servants.
Aut prodesse solent, aut delectare. â€”
London, printed by Nich. and John Okes for James Becket, and are to be fold at his shop at the inner temple near the gate. 1637.

div.head: The prologue to the stage.
div.l: To give content to this most curious age,
The gods themselves we have brought down to the stage,
And figured them in planets, made even hell
Deliver up the furies, by no spell,
(Saving the muse's rapture) further, we
Have trafficked by their help; no history
We have left unrifled, our pens have, been dipped
As well in opening each hid manuscript,
As tracts more vulgar, whether read, or sung
In our domestic, or more foreign tongue:
Of fairy elves, nymphs of the sea, and land;
The lawns and groves, no number can be scanned
Which we have not given feet to, nay 'tis known,
That when our chronicles have barren grown
Of story, we have all invention stretched,
Dived low as to the centre, and then reached
Unto the primum mobile above:
(Nor scaped things intermediate) for your love,
These have been acted often, all have passed
Censure; of which some live, and some are cast:
For this in agitation, stay the end,
Though nothing please, yet nothing can offend.

list.item: The King of England. The prince of England.
The Earl of Chester. Corporal cock.
The lord Bonvile. An host of the ordinary
The Princess. Four young gallants at the ordinary.
Isabella the marshal's eldest daughter. A servant.
Margaret, the marshal's younger daughter. A bawd.
The lady Mary Audley. Two courtesans.
Two gentlemen in a brothel-house. Attendants, etc.

div.head: The royal King, and the loyal subject.
Scaena prima.
div.stage: Enter the King of England, the lord Lacy, Clinton, Chester, and the marshal, Audley, and Bonvile.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Thus from the holy wars are we returned,
To, slumber in the summer of soft peace,
Since those proud enemies that late blasphemed
And spit their furies in the face of heaven,
Are now laid low in dust.

sp.speaker: Chester.
sp.l: Dread sovereign.
The heavens have showed their bounty unto us,
In guarding your most dear and sacred life
From opposite hatred, and that imminent peril
To which you were engaged.

sp.speaker: Clinton.
sp.l: When in one battle you were twice unhorsed,
Girt with the opposite ranks of infidels,
That had not timely rescue come from heaven,
Mortal assistance had been used in vain.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Ay, now you load me with a surplusage,
Of comprlesse debets this thrice valiant lord
My noble marshal, twice that perilous day
Did he bestride me, and beneath his targe.
Methought that instant did I lie as safe
As in my best and strongest citadel;
The whilst his bright sword like the bolt of Jove,
Pierced the steel-crests of barbarous infidels,
And flatted them with earth; although my subject,
Yet in this one thing thou hast proved my lord:
For when my life was forfeit to the wars,
Thou by thy valour didst redeem it freely,
And gavest it me, whilst thou engag'st thy life:
For which if ever by like chance of war,
Law's forfeiture, or our prerogative,
Thy life come in like danger, here we swear
By our earth's honours, and our hopes divine,
As thou for us, we'll ours engage for thine.

sp.speaker: Mart.
sp.l: You give my lord, to duty attributes
Too high for her submiss humility:
I am your vassal, and ten thousand lives
Of equal rank with mine, subjects and servants,
Be overrated if compared with yours.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: When I forget thee, may my operant parts
Each one forget their office: we create thee
Next to ourself of power, we but except
The name of King, all other dignities
We will communicate to thee our friend.

sp.speaker: Mart.
sp.l: May I no longer use these royaltiys royalties,
Or have the power to enjoy them, then I wholly
Devote them to your service.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.l: Noble marshal,
If I survive England's inheritance,
Or ever live to sit on Jacob's stone,
Thy love shall with my crown be hereditary.

sp.speaker: Mart.
sp.l: And gracious prince, since heaven hath been as liberal
To grace me with your favour, as my birth
was to endow me richly; all your graces
Shall with my great and ample revenues
Be ever to your virtues serviceable.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: We know it. and have been observers long
Of thy choice virtues neither could we yet
Fasten that love on thee, which came not home
With double use and ample recompense.

sp.speaker: Clint.
sp.l: These graces are beyond dimension,
They have nor height, nor depth, uncircumscribed,
And without bounds. He like abroad armed tree
O'ershadows us, and throw his spacious bows,
We that grow under cannot see the sun,
Nor taste the cheerful warmth of his bright beams.
These branches we must lop by fire or thunder,
Or by his shadowy arms be still kept under.

sp.speaker: Chest.
sp.l: I was born eagle-fighted, and to gaze
In the sun's forehead; I will brook no cloud
To stand betwixt me and his glorious fire,
I'll have full light, or none; either soar high,
Or else sink low; my ominous fate is cast,
Or to be first, or of all abjects last.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: You shall renowned martial feast for us
The ambassadors that come from foreign lands,
To gratulate our famous victories.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: I shall my lord, and give them entertainment
To England's honour, and to suit the place
Of which I bear the name.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: We doubt it not:
We understand lords, in these tedious wars
Some forward spirits have been at great expense
To furnish them like noble gentlemen;
And many spent most part of their revenues
In honour of their country, some undone
In pursuit of these wars: now if such come
For their relief by suit petitionary,
Let them have gracious hearing, and supply
Or by our service, or our treasury

sp.speaker: Audley.
sp.l: I have one kinsman hath spent all his land,
And is returned a beggar, and so tattered,
As that I can but blush to acknowledge him:
But in the wars he spent it, and for me,
Wars shall relieve him. He was a noble heir,
But what these lost, let other wars repair.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Lords all, once more we greet your safe return,
With general welcome, we invite you all
To feast with us, and joy what we have won,
Happiest in these, our marshal, and our son.

div.stage: Enter the clown and a Welshman.

sp.speaker: Clown.
sp.p: It seems thou hast not been in the wars my friend, but art new come up to London.

sp.speaker: Welch.
sp.p: Heaven pless thee from all his mercies, and his graces: it was told us in Wales, that you have great pig organ in Paul's, and pigger by a great deal than our organ at Rixam, which made me make my travels and my journeys on the pair hoof up to London, to have resolutions and certifications in that business, that when I venture into my countries and habitations, I may give notice to mine uncle, rice ap Davy, ap Morgan, ap Evan, ap Jones, ap Geoffrey. I pray where about stands Paul's church, can you tell her?

sp.speaker: Clowne.
sp.p: Overy easily; stand with thy face that way, and follow thy nose, and thou wilt be there presently. But dost thou hear Briton, take my word, our organ of Paul's is much bigger and better than yours of Rixam, by as much as Paul's church is bigger and better than saint Pancridge.

sp.speaker: Welch.
sp.p: Awe man, you prittle and prattle nothing but leasings and untruths: now will you but ease your posteriors a little, and I will quickly show you your organ of Paul's.

sp.speaker: Clown.
sp.p: Very good, I like your demonstration well; but dost thou think your organ of Rixam can compare with ours for all that?

sp.speaker: Welch.
sp.p:
Lend me but your ears and your apprehensions, and
I will make you easily to acknowledge your errors.

sp.speaker: Clown.
sp.p: But first show me your case in which you carry your two pair of organs, sure those flops will not hold them: but in the mean time walk with me to the next red lettuce, and I will give thee two cans, and wet thine organ-pipes well I warrant thee.

sp.speaker: Welch.
sp.p: I will take your courtesies, and if ever I shall meet you in Glamorgan, or Rednockshire, I will make bold to requite some part of your kindnesses.

div.stage: A loud winding of horns within.

sp.speaker: Clown.
sp.p: The very noise of that horn hath frighted my courtesy, but all's one, farewell for this time, and at our next meeting ten to one I will be as good as my word.

sp.speaker: Welch.
sp.p: Say you so man, why then Cad keep you from all his mercies, and good fortunes, and make us all his servants.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Come, we will to the chase, be near us marshal,
I'll try today which of our two good steeds
Can speed it best; let the most swift take both.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: So please your grace, but I shall surely lose;
Yours is the best for proof, though mine for show.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: That will we try, the wager grows not deep
Equals the lay, and what we win, we'll keep,
Mount, mount.

sp.speaker: Chester.
sp.l: Greater and greater still, no plot, no trick
To have him quite removed from the King's grace,
To slander him?

sp.speaker: Clin.
sp.l: The King will lend no ear
To any just complaint that's made of him;
What can our scandals do then?

sp.speaker: Chest.
sp.l: Challenge him
Of treason then, and that may haply call
His loyalty into suspect and question,
Which in the King at least will breed a coldness,
If not a deadness of affection.

sp.speaker: Clint.
sp.l: Of treason? say he crave the combat then,
for that's the least he can; which of us two
Shall combat him? I know his blows too well,
Not I.

sp.speaker: Chest.
sp.l: I should be loath.

sp.speaker: Clin.
sp.l: How do you relish this?
His virtue and his bounty won him grace,
On that we'll build to ruin all his favours,
And work him to disgrace.

sp.speaker: Chest.
sp.l: Pray teach me how?

sp.speaker: Clin.
sp.l: First, praise him to the King, give all his virtues
Double their due, add unto every thing,
Ay, and hyperbolize in all his deeds:
Let his known virtues be the common theme
Of our discourse to stale him, rate his worth,
To equalise, if not to exceed the King:
This cannot but beget distaste at least.

sp.speaker: Chest.
sp.l: But further.

sp.speaker: Clin.
sp.l: Thus; then fall off from his praise,
And question his best deeds, as it may be
His noble bounty is but popular grace,
And his humility but inward pride:
His vulgar suffrage and applause abroad,
A way to climb and seat himself aloft,
You understand me?

sp.speaker: Chest.
sp.l: Fully; come to horse,
And as we ride, our further plots digest,
To find what may disturb, what aid us best.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Spur to the King, his steed's unshod before,
The ways be stony, and he'll spoil his beast:
Here take these shoes and hammer, brought of purpose
For mine own use.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: My lord, have you plucked the shoes off from your own horse, to set them on another's, a thousand to one but you will spoil your own gelding quite.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: No matter, do as I command thee sirrah;
hollow him straight, I know he loves that horse,
And would not ride him bare for any gold.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: Your horse is as good as his I am sure, and I think you love him as well.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: No matter, if he ask thee where thou hadst them,
Tell him, thou broughtest them with thee for my use.
Away, I'll gallop after, and overtake thee.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: Put your shoes on another horses' feet, and let your own go barefoot? A jest indeed.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: The King affects both his good horse and game, I'll help to further both.

div.stage: Enter the King, and marshal: wind horns.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: You have fetched me up at length, that's to your fortune,
Or my misfortune, for I lost a shoe.
Martial you ride well furnished to the field,

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: My lord, so horsemen should and I am glad
My man was so well furnished, and the rather
Since we are far from help; my man is cunning,
Your highness to his skill may trust your horse.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Thou couldst not have presented me a gift
I could have tasted better, for that beast
I much esteem: you were outstripped at length.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Till I was forced to alight, my horse with yours kept equal speed.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Our lords? now gentlemen,
How do you like the chase?

sp.speaker: Audl.
sp.l: 'Twas excellent.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Had not my horse been by mischance unshod,
My marshal here and I had led you still.

sp.speaker: Chest.
sp.l: You were the better horsed.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: And you the worst,
Witness the hugeness of your way behind:
Is not my horse yet shod?

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.l: He is my lord.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Then let us mount again.

sp.speaker: Clin.
sp.l: Your horse my lord, is not in state to ride,
he wants two shoes before.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Whose doth, the marshal's?

sp.speaker: Mart.
sp.l: Oft such mischance; happen.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Were you furnished
For us, and for yourself kept no supply?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: So I may have my lord to furnish you,
I care not how myself want.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Apprehension help me, for every circumstance apply
Thou hast done me an unwonted courtesy;
You spied my loss first.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: I did my lord.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: And then alighted.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: True.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Upon my life 'tis so,
To unshoe thine own good steed, and furnish mine,
Was't not? upon thy life resolve me true.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: What I have done my lord, I did to you.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: You will exceed me still, and yet my courtesy
Shall rank with thine; for this great duty shown,
I pay thee thus, both steeds are now thine own.

sp.speaker: Clint.
sp.l: They wager love.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: The best thing I can do
In me is duty; the worst, grace in you.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Th' art ours; come mount, we wil return to court,
To order the great tournament prepared
To do our son grace; in which we entreat
Marshal, your aid, because your skill is great.

sp.speaker: Corporal
sp.p: We have visited all our familiars, is it not now time that we revisit our captain?

sp.speaker: Cock.
sp.p: With all my heart good corporal, but it had not been amiss, if we had gone to Burchen-lane first to have suited us: and yet it is a credit for a man of the sword to go threadbare, because by his apparel he may be taken to be an old soldier.

sp.speaker: Corporal
sp.p: Cocke, thy father was a fresh water soldier, thou are not; thou hast been powdered, witness thy flax and touchbox.

sp.speaker: Cocke.
sp.p: But who comes yonder, my match? I am glad I have met thee.

sp.speaker: Match.
sp.p: I knew cock, at one time or other thou wouldst meet with thy match. What, shall we go to my captain's lodging?

sp.speaker: Corporal
sp.l: Spare that pains, yonder he appears in his colours.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: fortun'de la guere; I that have flourished, no colours like me, nay, no trumpet thou in his highest key, have nothing now but rags to flourish; I that have faced the enemy, have not so much as any facing left me: were my suit but as well pointed as I have seen some, and stood I but in the midst of my followers, I might say I had nothing about me but tag and rag. I am descended nobly; for I am descended so low, that all the clothes of my back are scarce worth a noble: I was born to thousands, and yet a thousand to one, they will now scarce acknowledge me where I was born.

sp.speaker: Corporal
sp.p: Health to our worthy captain,

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: Thanks my most worthy soldiers; and yet if I should examine your worths, what at the most could all you make?

sp.speaker: Corporal
sp.p: I would not have your worship to examine our outsides.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: And for your insides I'll pass my word.

sp.speaker: Cock.
sp.p: Cannot all your worship's credit afford you a new suit?

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: Credit me, no; my revenues were a thousand a year, part of which I lavished amongst gallants, rioted in taverns, havocked in ordinaries; and when my estate began to ebb, as my last refuge, I laid all my hopes upon the last wars, but failing there, (As the world imagines) I am returned as you see. The King hath promised supply and relief to all that have spent their estates in his expeditions, but many like myself have been born to be poor, that scorn to be beggars; as many have been born to be rich, that can never leave it; the truth is, I am myself as my proceedings will express me further.

sp.speaker: Corporal
sp.p: Will you cashier us captain, or shall we follow your future fortunes?

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: You shall not leave me; my purpose is to try the humours of all my friends, my allies, my ancient associates, and see how they will respect me in my supposed poverty: though I lose their acquaintance, I will lose none of my retinue. How say you gentlemen, will you copart with me in this my dejectedness?

sp.speaker: Corporal
sp.p: As I am corporal, so will I prove true squire to thy body.

sp.speaker: Cock.
sp.p: And as I am true cock, so will I crow at thy service, wait on thee with a comb for thy head, with fire to thy piece, with water to thy hands, and be cock sure in any employment whatsoever.

sp.speaker: Match.
sp.p: And as I am true match, I shall scorn that any of them shall o'ermatch me in duty.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: Attend me then; if I rise, you shall ascend; if fall, I will lie flat with you. First then I will make some trial of my friends at the court, and in good time: here's the King.

div.stage: Sound, enter the King discoursing with Chester, and Clinton, Audley, and Bonvile.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: You have persuaded much, and I begin
To censure strangely, of his emulous love.

sp.speaker: Chest.
sp.l: Further my lord, what can his smoothness mean,
His courtesy, and his humility,
But as fly baits to catch the people's hearts,
And wean them from your love.

sp.speaker: Clin.
sp.l: Doth he not strive
In all things to exceed your courtesy,
Of purpose to outshine your royal deeds,
And daze I your brightness, that himself may shine?
Is he not only popular my liege?
Is not the people's suffrage sole to him,
Whilst they neglect your fame, his train doth equal,
If not exceed yours, still his chamber thronged
With store of suitors: where the marshal lies,
There is the court, all eyes are bent on him,
and on his glories; there's no theme abroad,
But how he saved you from the pagans sword,
How his sole hand sways, guides, and guards the realm.

sp.speaker: Chest.
sp.l: Think but my lord on his last game at chess,
'Twas his past odds, but when he saw you moved,
With what a sly neglect he lost the mate,
Only to make you bound to him.

sp.speaker: Clin.
sp.l: For all the favours, graces, honours, loves
Bestowed upon him from your bounteous hand,
His cunning was to think to quit you all,
And pay you with a horse-shoe.

sp.speaker: Chest.
sp.l: In the tournament
Made by the prince your son, when he was peerless,
And without equal, this ambitious marshal
Strives to exceed, and did; but when he saw
Your highness moved to see the prince disgraced,
He lost the prize; but how? that all the people
Might see it given, not forfeit, which did add
Rather than derogate: briefly my lord,
His courtesy is all ambition.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: And well it may be; is he not our vassal?
Why should the marshal then contend with us.
To exceed in any virtue? we observe him.
His popularity, how affable
He's to the people; his hospitality,
Which adds unto his love; his forwardness,
To entertain ambassadors, and feast them,
Which though he do't upon his proper charge,
And for our honour, yet it may be thought
A smoothness, and a cunning, to grow great;
It must be so. A project we intend
To prove him faithless, or a perfect friend.

sp.speaker: Chest.
sp.l: It takes, these jealous thoughts we must pursue,
And to his late doubts still add something new.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.l: Your speech being ended, now comes in my cue.
My honourable lord.

sp.speaker: Chest.
sp.l: What beggar's this?

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.l: Beggar my lord? I never begged of you:
But were I a beggar, I might be a courtier's fellow:
Could I beg suits my lord as well as you,
I need not go thus clad; or were you free
From begging as I am, you might rank me.

sp.speaker: Chest.
sp.l: Comparisons? Away.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.l: Folly and pride
In silks and lace their imperfections show,
But let pure virtue come in garments torn
To beg relief she gets a courtly scorn:
My lord you know me?

sp.speaker: Clin.
sp.l: I have seen that face.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.l: Why 'tis the same it was, it is no changeling,
It bears the selfsame front; 'tis not like yours,
Paled with the least disgrace, or passed with brags,
That smiles upon gay clothes, and frowns on rags.
Mine's steadfast as the sun, and free as fate;
Whose equal eyes look upon want and state.

sp.speaker: Clin.
sp.p: And doth not mine so too? Pray what's your business?

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: Only that you would know me: the King's favour hath made you a baron, and the King's wars have made me a bare one: there's less difference in the accent of the word, than in the cost of our weeds: this is the same face you were once acquainted with though not the same habit: I could know your face, though your diseased body were wrapped in sheepskins.

sp.speaker: Clin.
sp.p: This fellow offends me.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: Go churl, pass free, thou knowest my forfeit lands, though forgettest me: nay, you would be going too, you are as afraid of a torne suit, as a younger brother of a sergeant, a rich corn-master of a plentiful year, or a troublesome attorney to hear of suits put to compromise.
sp.l: Sir. I must challenge you, you are my kinsman;
My grandsire was the first that raised the name
Of Bonvile to this height, but lord to see
That you are grown a lord, and know not me.

sp.speaker: Bonu.
sp.l: Cousin, I know you, you have been an unthrift,
And lavished what you had; had I so done,
I might have ebbed like you, where I now flow.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: Yet I can purchase that, which all the wealth you have will never win you.

sp.speaker: Bon.
sp.l: And what's that I pray?

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.l: Wit: is the word strange to you, wit?

sp.speaker: Bon.
sp.l: Whither wilt thou?

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.l: True,
Wit will to many ere it come to you.

sp.speaker: Bon.
sp.l: Feed you upon your purchase, I'll keep mine.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.l: Have you the wit to do't?

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.l: I have wit to buy,
And you to sell, which is the greater gain?
Cousin I'll keep my wealth, keep you your brain.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.l: The wealth of Midas choke thee ere thou'rt old,
And even the bread thou feedest on change to gold.
My lord, you hear how I pray for my kindred,
I have a little more charity for my friend: with you
I have some business.

sp.speaker: Aud.
sp.l: I am in haste now.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.l: I pray you stay.

sp.speaker: Audl.
sp.l: Not now indeed.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.l: Pardon, for here's no way
Before you hear me.

sp.speaker: Aud.
sp.l: Prithee be brief.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.l: Your daughter lives I hope.

sp.speaker: Aud.
sp.l: What's that to thee?

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.l: Somewhat 'twill prove, ay and concerning me;
Before I laid my fortunes on these wars.
And was in hope to thrive, by your consent,
Nay, by your motion our united hearts
Were made more firm by contract; well you know
We were betrothed.

sp.speaker: Aud.
sp.l: Sir, I remember't not.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.l: I do, and thus proceed:
I was in hope to have raised my fortunes high,
and with them to have pulled her by degrees
Unto that eminence at which I aim:
I ventured for it, but instead of wealth
I purchased naught but wounds. Honour I had,
And the repute of valour; but my lord,
These simply of themselves are naked titles,
Respectless, without price, and bombast wealth,
And to the purblind world show seeming bad,
Behold in me their shapes, they thus go clad.

sp.speaker: Aud.
sp.l: You said you would be brief.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.l: All that I had,
I spent upon my soldiers, we took no spoil.
The wars have grated on me e'en to this
That you now see: now my last refuge is,
To raise myself by her.

sp.speaker: Aud.
sp.l: And spend her means
As thou hast done thine own vile unthrift? no,
I know no contract.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.l: I have one to show.

sp.speaker: Aud.
sp.l: No matter; think'st thou that I'll vent my bags
To suit in satin him that jets in rags?

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.l: The world's all of one heart, this blaze I can,
All love the money, none esteems the man.
These be our friends at court, and fine ones too,
Are they not pray? where be our followers?

sp.speaker: Cock.
sp.p: Here noble captain.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: You see how our friends grace us, what hopes we have to prefer you?

sp.speaker: Corporal
sp.p: I see sufficient: captain, I will discharge myself, I mean to seek elsewhere for preferment.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: All leave me if you please; but him that stays, if e'er I mount, I'll with my fortunes raise.

sp.speaker: Match.
sp.p: Captain, I desire your pass, I mean to march along with my corporal.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: Wilt thou go too?

sp.speaker: Cock.
sp.p:
I leave you? who I? for a little diversity, for a wet storm? no sir, though your outsides fall away, I'll cleave
as close to you as your linings.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: Gramercy yet, away without reply?

sp.speaker: Corporal
sp.p: Foutre for thy base service.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: Away, 'sfoot how am I fallen out of my humour? and yet this strangeness of my nearest friends and alliance deserves a little cotemplating; is't possible, that even lords, that have the best educating, whose ears are frequent to the most fluent discourse, that live in the very brain of the land, the court, that these should be gulled with shadows, and not be able to distinguish a man when they see him; thou knowest me, yet these do not.

sp.speaker: Cock.
sp.p: Why may not a poor man have as good eyes as another? their ears indeed may be larger than mine, but I can see as far without spectacles as the best lord in the land.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: These superficial lords that think every thing to be as it appears, they never question a man's wit, his discretion, his language, his inward virtues, but as he seems, he passes.

sp.speaker: Cock.
sp.l: I warrant if I should look like an ass,
They would take me for one too.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: The next I try is my betrothed, if she acknowledge this hand that hath received hers, this heart, this face, and knows the person from the garment, I shall say, woman, there is more virtue in thee than man.

sp.speaker: Cock.
sp.p: There's no question of that; for they say, they will hold out better: but sir, if we be no better habited, I make a question how we shall get in at the court-gate; for I'll assure you your fashion is not in request at the court.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: My virtue is not to be imitated; I'll hold my purpose though I be kept back, and venture lashing in the porter's lodge. Come, follow me, I will go see my mistress, though girt with all the ladies of the court:
sp.l: Though ragged virtue oft may be kept out,
No grate so strongly kept above the centre,
But asses with gold laden, free may enter.

div.head: Scaena secunda.
div.stage: Enter the prince, the Princess, the marshal, and the lady Marry Audley.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.l: Lord marshal, we are much in debt to you,
For by your favour we obtained the prize
In the last tourney: we acknowledge it.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: I could not love my sovereign gracious prince,
Without extent of duty to the son.

sp.speaker: Princess.
sp.l: 'Twas nobly plied on both sides, both had honour;
Yet brother to be modest in your praise,
You had the best.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.l: You please to grace me sister.
Martial, I hear you are a widower late:
How long is't since your beauteous countess died?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: My lord, you make me now unsoldier-like
For get the name of marshal, to become
A passionate husband; her remembrance draws
Tears from mine eyes: she died some three months since,
Good lady she's now gone.

sp.speaker: Princess.
sp.l: A kind husband
I'll warrant him: if e'er I chance to bride,
Heaven grant I find no worse.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.l: Have you no children by her?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Two sweet girls,
Now all my hopes and solace of this earth,
Whom next the zeal I owe unto my King,
I prize above the world.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.l: Why noble sir,
Are they not brought up to be trained at court,
To attend our sister?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: They are young and tender,
And ere I teach them fashion, I would gladly
Train them in virtue, and to arm their youth
Against the smooth and amorous baits of court.

sp.speaker: Princess.
sp.l: As kind a father as a husband now:
If e'er I chance to wed, such heaven grant me.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.l: Why heaven may hear your prayer: here's one
I warrant that dreams not on a husband.

sp.speaker: Princess.
sp.l: Yet ere long
She may both dream, and speak as much as I.
No question but she thinks as much already;
And were here voice and her election free,
She would not stick to say this man for me.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.l: You make the lady blush.

sp.speaker: Princess.
sp.l: Why to change face,
They say in modest maids are signs of grace:
Yet many that like her hold down the head,
Will never change colour when they're once in bed.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.l: You'll put the lady out of countenance quite.

sp.speaker: Princess.
sp.l: Not out of heart; for all of her complexion,
Show in their face the fire of their affection:
And even the modest wives, this know we too,
Oft blush to speak what is no shame to do.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Lady, the Princess doth but try your spirit,
And prove your cheek, yet do not take it ill,
He'll one day come will act the husband's part.

sp.speaker: Princess.
sp.p: Here enters one, I hope it be not he.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: Attend me sirrah into the presence, and if any of the guard repulse thee, regard him not.

sp.speaker: Cocke.
sp.p: I'll march where my captain leads, were't into the presence of the great termagant.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: My duty to the prince, madam your favour, lord marshal, yours.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.p: What will the fellow do?

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: Lady, your lip.

sp.speaker: Princess.
sp.l: My lord, how like you this?
She'd blush to speak, that doth not blush to kiss.

sp.speaker: Cocke.
sp.p: Well said mistress.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.p: A good bold fellow.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: You are not ashamed to acknowledge me in this good company: I have brought thee all that the wars have left of me; were I better worth, 'twere all thine; thou canst have no more of the cat but his skin, I have brought thee home the same eyes that first saw thee, the same tongue that first courted thee, the same hand that first contracted thee, and the same heart that first affected thee: more I have not, less I cannot: nay quickly sweet wench, and let me know what to trust to.

sp.speaker: Lady Marry.
sp.l: Were you more worth, I could not love you more,
Or less, affect you less; you have brought me home
All that I love, your self, and you are welcome.
I gave no faith to money, but a man,
And that I cannot lose possessing you:
'Tis not the robe or garment I affect,
For who would marry with a suit of clothes?
Diamonds, though set lead, retain their worth,
And leaden knives may have a golden sheath.
My love is to the jewel, not the case,
And you my jewel are.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: Why god a-mercy wench: come sirrah.

sp.speaker: Cock
sp.p: Here's a short horse soon curried.

sp.speaker: Princess.
sp.p: Is this your sweetheart? I had need wish you much joy, for I see but a little towards: where did you take him up by the highway, or did you not fall in love with him hanging on a gibbet?

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.p: What is he for heaven's sake? can no man give him his true character?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: I can my lord, he's of a noble house,
A Bonvile, and great heir; but being profuse,
And lavish in his nonage, spent the most
Of his known means, and hoping now at last
To raise his fortunes by the wars now ceased,
His hopes have failed him, yet we know him valiant
And fortunate in service. One whose mind
No fortune can deject, no favour raise
Above his virtue's pitch.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.l: If he be such,
We'll move the King in his behalf, and help
To cherish his good parts.

sp.speaker: Chest.
sp.l: My lord the prince,
The King calls for you; for he dines today
In the great hall with great solemnity,
And his best state: lord marshal, you this day
Must use your place, and wait, so all the lords.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.p: Come, we'll go see the King.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: I shall attend your grace.

sp.speaker: Princess.
sp.p: And in faith lady can you be in love with this rag of honour?

sp.speaker: Lady ma.
sp.l: Madam, you know I am my father's heir,
My possibilities may raise his hopes
To their first height: should I despise my hand
In a torne glove, or taste a poisonous draught
Because presented in a cup of gold?
Virtue will last when wealth flies, and is gone:
Let me drink nectar though in earth or stone.

sp.speaker: Princess.
sp.p: But say your father now, as many fathers are, prove a true worldling, and rather than bestow thee on one dejected, disinherit thee? how then?

sp.speaker: Laay ma.
sp.l: My father is my father, but my husband,
He is myself: my resolution is
To profess constancy, and keep mine honour;
And rather than to Queen it where I hate,
Beg where I love: I wish no better fate.

sp.speaker: Princess.
sp.p: By my faith good counsel; if I live long enough, it may be I may have the grace to follow it.

div.stage: Sound: enter two banquets brought forth, at one the King and the prince in their state, at the other the lords: the marshal with his staff and key, and other offices born before him to wait on the King.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: This anniversary do we yearly keep
In memory of our late victories.
In joy of which we make a public feast,
And banquet all our peers thus openly.
Sit lords, those only we appoint to wait,
Attend us for this day: and now to crown
Our festival, we will begin this health.
Who's that so near our elbow? Martial? you?
Stand off we wish you, further.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Me my lord?

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Ay you my lord.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Your highness' will's a law,
I shall obey.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: You are too near us yet: what are we King,
Or have we countermanders?

sp.speaker: Chest.
sp.p: Note you that?

sp.speaker: Clint.
sp.p: Now it begins.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: I fear some sycophants
Have dealt ignobly with us to the King:
No matter I am armed with innocence,
And that dares front all danger.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Lords this health:
sp.stage: The King drinks, they all stand.
sp.l: See it go round, 'twas to our victory.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: With pardon, can your highness that remember, and so forget me?

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Thou dost prompt me well,
You are our marshal.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: I have used that place.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Your staff? support it, and resolve me thus:
Which of yond lords there seated at the board,
Hast thou been most in opposition with?
Or whom dost thou least favour?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: I love all:
But should you ask me who hath wronged me most,
Then should I point out Chester.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Chester then,
Bear him that staff, give't up into his hand,
Say, I commend me to him by the name
Of our high marshal; take your place below,
And let him wait on us: what do you pause?
Or shall we twice command?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: I'll do't my lord:
Chester, the King commends his love to you,
And by my mouth he styles you by the name
Of his high marshal, which this staff of office
Makes good to you; my place I thus resign,
And give't up freely as it first was mine.
You must attend the King, it is a place
Of honour Chester, and of great command,
Use it with no less modesty than he
That late enjoyed it, and resigns it thee.

sp.speaker: Chest.
sp.l: I need not your instruction; the King's bounty
Bestows it freely, and I take my place.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: And I mine here, th'allegiance that I owe him
Bids me accept it, were it yet more low.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Attend us Chester, wait upon our cup,
It is an honour due to you this day.

sp.speaker: Chest.
sp.l: I shall my lord.

sp.speaker: Clin.
sp.p: O my lord you are welcome, we have not had your company amongst us long.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: You ever had my heart, though the King's service
Commanded still my person: I am eased
Of a great burden so the King rest pleased.

sp.speaker: Aud.
sp.p: I have not seen a man hath born his disgrace with more patience; especially to be forced with his own hand to deliver up his honours to his enemy.

sp.speaker: Bonu.
sp.p: It would have troubled me, I should not brook it.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Command you fellow give his golden key
To the lord Clinton; henceforth we debar him
Access unto our chamber, see it done.

sp.speaker: Chest.
sp.l: The King commands you to give up your key
Unto that lord that nears you: henceforth sir,
You to his person are denied access,
But when the King commands.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Say to my liege,
The proudest foe he hath, were he an emperor,
Should not have forced the least of these from me:
But I acknowledge these, and all I have,
To be sole his; my life too, which as willingly
to please him I will send: I thank his highness
That sees so into my debility,
That he hath care to ease me of these loads
That have oppressed me long; so sir 'tis done:
Come lords, now let's be merry, and drink round,
After great tempests we a calm have found.

sp.speaker: Aud.
sp.p: This lord is of an unwonted constancy, he entertains his disgraces as merrily as a man dies that is tickled to death.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Cannot all this stir his impatience up?
I'll search his breast but I will find his gall:
Command him give his staff of council up,
We will bestow it elsewhere where we please.

sp.speaker: Chest.
sp.p: The King would have you to forbear the council, and to give up your staff.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: I shall turn man,
Kings cannot force to bear more than we can.

sp.speaker: Chest.
sp.l: Sir, are you moved?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Those that are wronged may speak:
My lord, I let you know my innocence,
And that my true and unstained loyalty
Deserves not this disgrace: none ever bore
Like eminence with me that hath discharged it
With better zeal and conscience: for my service
Let my wounds witness, I have some to show;
That had I not my body interposed,
Had been your scars: all my deserved honours
You have bestowed upon my enemies,
Ay such as have whole skins, â€”
And never bled but for their ease and health.
You might with as much justice take my life
As seize my honours: howsoe'er my lord
Give me free leave to speak but as I find,
I ever have been true, you now unkind.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Will you contest?
What have you sir that is not held from us?
Or what can your own virtue purchase you
without our grace? Are not your fortunes, favours,
And your revenues ours? where should they end
But where they first began? have we not power
To give our own? or must we ask your counsel,
To grace where you appoint? need we a guardian,
Or aim you at the place?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: O my dread King,
It sorrows me that you misprise my love,
And with more freedom I could part with life
Than with your grace: my offices alas,
They were my troubles, but to want your favours,
That only thus afflicts my loyal thoughts,
And makes me bold to term your grace unkind.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Sir, we command you to abandon court,
And take it as a favour that we now
Not question of your life; without reply
Leave us.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: I'll leave the court as I would leave my burden,
But from your highness in this kind to part,
Is as my body should foretake my heart.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Shall we not be ourself, or shall we brook
Competitors in reign? act what we do
By other men's appointment? he being gone,
We are unrivalled; we'll be sole, or none.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.p: The marshal's gone in discontent my liege.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Pleased, or not pleased, if we be England's King,
And mightiest in the sphere in which we move,
We'll shine alone, this Phaeton cast down,
We'll state us now midst of our best affected:
Our new created marshal first lead on,
Whose loyalty we now must build upon.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.l: Sir, now attend me, I'll to the ordinary,
And see if any of my ancient friends will take note of me.
Where's the good man? within?

sp.speaker: Clown.
sp.p:
There's none dwells here; you may speak with the
master of the house if you will.

sp.speaker: Crown.
sp.p: Captain, captain, I have descried an host.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: An host? where? which way march they?

sp.speaker: Clown.
sp.p: Mine host of the house, see where he marches.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: Here take my cloak, what is't not dinner-time? Are there no gallants come yet?

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p: Why sir, do you mean to dine here today?

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: Here do I mean to crunch, to munch, to eat, to feed, and be fat my fine Cullapolis.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p: You must pardon me sir, my house entertains none but gentlemen; if you will stand at gate, when dinner's done, I'll help you to some fragments.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: Sirrah, if your house be free for gentlemen, it is fit for me; thou seest I keep my man, I've crowns to spend with him that's bravest here: I'll keep my room in spite of silks and satins.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p: I would I were well rid of this rugamuffin.

sp.speaker: 1. Gent.
sp.p: How goes the day?

sp.speaker: 2. Gent.
sp.p: It cannot yet be old, because I see no more gallants come.

sp.speaker: 1. Gent.
sp.p: Mine host, what's here?

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p: A tatterdemalion, that stays to sit at the ordinary today.

sp.speaker: 2. Gent.
sp.p: Dost know him?

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p: I did when he was flush, and had the crowns; but since he grew poor, he is worn quite out of my remembrance. He is a decayed captain, and his name is Bonvile.

sp.speaker: 1. Gent.
sp.p: I would he would leave this place, and rank himself with his companions.

sp.speaker: 2. Gent.
sp.p: Morrow gentlemen.

sp.speaker: 3. Gent.
sp.p: The morning's past, 'tis midday at the least.

sp.speaker: 4. Gent.
sp.p: What is the room so empty?

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.l: And please your worships.
Here's more by one than it can well receive.

sp.speaker: 3. Gent.
sp.p: What tatter's that that walks there?

sp.speaker: 4. Gent.
sp.p: If he will not leave the room, kick him down stairs.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.l: There's never a silken outside in this company
That dares present a foot to do that office:
I'll toss that heel a yard above his head
That offers but a spurn.

sp.speaker: 1. Gent.
sp.l: Can we not be private?

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.l: I am a man like you perhaps well bred,
Nor want I coin, for hark, my pocket's chink:
I keep my man to attend me more perhaps,
Than some can do that go in costlier silk
Are you so fearful of a ragged suit?
They were first paid for ere they were put on;
A man may question whether yours were so.
Who kicks first, ha, come; have you mind to game?
I'll cast, or set at thus much; will you card
A rest for this? no? then let's to dinner:
Come serve in meat.

sp.speaker: 1. Gent.
sp.p: Mine host, prithee put this fellow out of the room, and let him not drop his shoe-clouts here.

sp.speaker: 2. Gent.
sp.p: 'Sfoot dost thou mean we shall go lousy out of the house?

sp.speaker: 3. Gent.
sp.p: If he will not go out by fair means, send for a constable.

sp.speaker: 4. Gent.
sp.p: And send him to Bridewell ordinary; whipping cheer is best for him.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p: Nay pray sir leave my house, you see the gentlemen will not endure your company.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.l: Mine host, thou knewest me in my flourishing prime:
I was the first brought custom to thine house,
Most of my means I spent here to enrich thee;
And to set thee up, I've cast down myself.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p: I remember sir some such matter, but you see the times change. Nay, will you leave the gentlemen?

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.l: The lease of this house hadst thou not from me?
Did I not give thee both the fine and rent?

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p: I must needs say you were bountiful when you had it, but in troth sir, if you will not be gone, i shall be forced to turn you out by the head and shoulders.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.l: And is not all this worth the trusting for an ordinary?

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.l: Nay if you prate, I shall use you somewhat extraordinary.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: Down with the rogue.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.l: Since you hate calms, and will move stormy weather,
Now host and guest shall all down stairs together.

sp.speaker: Clown.
sp.l: Ah well done master, tickle them noble captain.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: Come cock I have taken some of their stomachs away from them before dinner.

div.stage: Enter the marshal with his two men, and his two daughters.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: We are at peace now, and in threatened death
We do enjoy new life: my only comforts,
The image of my late deceased wife,
Now have I time to surfeit on your sight,
Which court-employments have debarred me long.
O fortune, thou didst threaten misery,
And thou hast paid me comfort; need we ought
That we should seek the suffrage of the court?
Are we not rich? are we not well revenued?
Are not the country-pleasures far more sweet
Than the court-cares? Instead of balling suiters
Our ears receive the music of the hound;
For mounting pride and lofty ambition,
We in the air behold the falcon's tower,
And in that moral mock those that aspire.
O my good King, instead of threat and wrong,
Thou hast brought me rest which I have wished so long.

sp.speaker: Isabella.
sp.l: Sir we have long been orphans in the country,
Whilst you still followed your affairs at court;
We heard we had a father by our guardian,
But scarce till now could we enjoy your sight.

sp.speaker: Katherine.
sp.l: Nor let it seem offensive to your love,
That we in your retirement should take pride,
The King in this pursues our greater happiness,
And quickens most where he would most destroy.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: You are mine own sweet girls and in your virtues
I place my sole bliss; you are all my honours,
my favours, state, and offices at court:
What are you not? Let the King take my lands,
And my possession, and but leave me you,
He leaves me rich; more would I not desire,
And less he cannot grant.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.l: One from the King
Attends your honour, and his urgency
Craves quick dispatch.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Ladies withdraw a little,
I long to know what mischief's now afoot;
We'll front it be it death, ay and march towards it.
A chair, admit the herald, let him in;
We are armed 'gainst what can come, our breast is true,
And that's one maxim, what is forced is wrong,
We can both keep our heart and guide our tongue.

div.stage: Enter the servant ushering in Chester.

sp.speaker: Chest.
sp.l: Sir, the King greets you, and commands you effect
His will in this you know the character.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: My good lord marshal you are welcome hither,
These lines I kiss because they came from him.

sp.speaker: Chest.
sp.l: You'll like the letter better than the style:
Ha, change your face? is your blood moved to the tide,
Or ebbs it to your heart?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Thou hast two daughters,
Fair by report her whom thou lovest best
Send to the court it is thy King's behest,
Do this on thy allegiance,

sp.speaker: Chest:
sp.l: Sir your answer?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: I pray sir deal with men in misery
Like one that may himself be miserable:
Insult not too much upon men distressed,
Play not too much upon my wretchedness;
The noble minds still will not when they can.

sp.speaker: Chest.
sp.l: I cannot stay for answer pray be brief.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: You are more welcome than your message sir,
And yet that's welcome coming from my King;
Pray sir forbear me, 'tis the King's command,
and you shall know mine answer instantly
Receive him nobly.

sp.speaker: Chest.
sp.l: I shall wait your pleasure.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Malice, revenge, displeasure Envy, hate,
I had thought that you had only dwelled at court,
And that the country had been clear and free:
But from King's wraths no place I find is safe
My fairest daughter? had the King commanded
One of my hands, I had sent it willingly;
But her! yet Kings must not be dallied with,
Somewhat I must resolve to breed of force
Treason or to my blood, or to my King,
False father or false or subject I must prove,
Be true to him I serve other I love,
Somewhat I must: my daughters, call them in:
Leave them and us.
Ladies I must be blunt, the king's displeased
And hearing of two children whom I love,
My patience and my loyalty to try,
Commands that she whom I love best must die.

sp.speaker: Isab
sp.l: Die? Alas chat's nothing; must nor all men so?
And doth not heaven crown martyred innocence?
I was afraid my lord the King had seen
To have strumpeted the fairest for oft of your blood:
An innocent death my lord is crown of rest,
Then let me die as her whom you love best.

sp.speaker: Kath.
sp.l: If but to die, prove that you love me then;
Death were most welcome to confirm your love.
Alas my sister she: hath not the heart
To look upon a rough tormenter's face:
I am bold and constant, and my courage great;
As token of your love then point out me.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Alas my girl for greater ills prepare,
Death would end yours and somewhat ease my sorrows:
What I must speak , contains heaven's greatest curse,
Search all the world, you can find naught so ill.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.l: Speak't at once.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Her whom I best affect.
The King intends to strumpet.

sp.speaker: Kath.
sp.l: Bless me heaven!

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Should he,

sp.speaker: Kath.
sp.l: By all my joys I'll sooner die
Than suffer it.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.l: And so by heaven will I.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Now you are mine indeed, who would forgo
One of these gems so fine, and valued so?
But passion give me leave, the King commands,
I must obey. The fairest he sent for;
None of my daughters have been seen at court,
Nor hath the ambitious Chester viewed them yet:
My eldest then shall go, come hither girl;
I send thee, (Heaven knows) whether to thy death
Or to thine honour; though he envy me,
Yet in himself the King is honourable,
And will not stretch his malice to my child.
The worst I fear, and yet the best I hope.
I charge thee then even by a father's name,
If the King deign to take thee to his bed
By name of Queen, if thou perceivest thyself
To be with child, conceal it even from him;
Next, when thou findest him affable and free,
Find out some talk about thy sister here,
As thus; thy father sent thee but in jest,
Thy sister's fairest, and I love her best.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.l: It may incense the King.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: What I intend
Is to myself, inquire no further of it.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.l: I shall perform your will, and thus resolved
To be a martyr e'er a concubine.
But if the King afford me further favour,
In my close bosom your last words I'll place.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Sister and sister part, be you not seen,
Bid her farewell, a martyr or a Queen.
They cannot speak for tears, alas for woe,
That force should part sister and sister thus,
And that the child and father of one heart,
Commands and powerful threats should thus divide.
But Chester stays, within there?

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.l: My lord?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Have you received Earl Chester honourably?

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.l: The noblest welcome that the house could yield
He hath had my lord, nothing was held too dear:
He much extols your bounty.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Usher him in, we are now ready for him.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.l: I shall my lord.

sp.speaker: Chest.
sp.l: Sir, I have stayed your leisure, now your answer?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: That I obey, the fairest of my girls
I send the King.

sp.speaker: Chest.
sp.l: I easily can believe
That this the fairest is, her like in court
Lives not; she is a present for a King.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Say to the King I give her but conditionally,
That if he like not this fairest of the two,
Unstained he will his gift send back again.

sp.speaker: Chest.
sp.l: I shall, come lady.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: My lord, I do not load you with commends
And duties which I could do to the King:
I know your love your memory may fail you,
And you them all may scatter by the way.
Do thou a father's duty thus in tears,
And send me how thou speedest to free these fears.

div.head: Actus tertius.
div.stage: Enter clown and the lady Marry.

sp.speaker: Mary.
sp.p: Came you from him?

sp.speaker: Clown.
sp.p:
Yes if it please your maidenship; my master sends you word he is the old man, and his suit is the old suit still,
and his clothes the old clothes: he scorns to be a change ling, or a shifter; he fears nothing but this, that he shall fall into the lord your father's hands for want of reparations.

sp.speaker: Mary.
sp.l: We know thy meaning, here bear him this gold,
And bid him suit him like the man he was,
Bid him to face the proudest he in court;
He shall not want whilst we have.

sp.speaker: Clown.
sp.p: That was out of my commission lady, gold tempts, I have commandment not to touch it; 'tis another thing he aims at: it is a thing, but I know not what manner of thing; but something it is, and he vows not to shift a shirt till he be further resolved: he only sends you commendations, and withal to know if you would stand to your word.

sp.speaker: Mary.
sp.l: He wrongs me to cast doubts:
Tell him I am the same I ever was,
And ever will continue as I am.
But that he should disdain this courtesy
Being in want, and coming too from me,
Doth somewhat trouble me.

sp.speaker: Clown.
sp.p: We want madam? you are deceived, we have store, of rags; plenty, of tatters; abundance, of jags; huge rends, witness our breeches; ground enough to command, for we can walk where we will, none will bid us to dinner; houses rent-free, and goodly ones to choose where we will; the Marshalsea, the counter, Newgate, Bridewell; and would a man desire to dwell in stronger buildings? and can you say that we are in want? No lady, my captain wants nothing but your love, and that he entreats you to send by me the bearer.

sp.speaker: Mary.
sp.l: I do, with all the best affection
A virgin can bestow upon her friend.

sp.speaker: Clown.
sp.p: I dare swear he is an honest man, but I dare not say he is a true man.

sp.speaker: Mary.
sp.p: How, not a true man?

sp.speaker: Clown.
sp.p:
No; for he hath sworn to steal you away,
and thus I prove it: if he steal you away, I am sure you will not go naked; he cannot steal you, but he must steal the clothes you have on; and he that steals apparel, what is he but a thief? and he that is a thief cannot be a true man ergo.

sp.speaker: Mary.
sp.l: That is not theft when men but steal their own,
And I am his, witness this diamond,
Which bear him, and thus say, that no disaster
Shall ever part me from his company.

sp.speaker: Clown.
sp.p: I shall bear this with as good will as you would bear him, utcunque volumus.

sp.speaker: Mary.
sp.l: What are we but our words? when they are past,
Faith should succeed, and that should ever last.
My father?

sp.speaker: Aud.
sp.l: Wots thou who's returned,
The unthrift Bonvile, ragged as a scarecrow,
The wars have gnawed his garments to the skin:
I met him, and he told me of a contract.

sp.speaker: Mary.
sp.l: Sir, such a thing there was.

sp.speaker: Aud.
sp.l: Upon condition if he came rich.

sp.speaker: Mary.
sp.l: I heard no such exception.

sp.speaker: Aud.
sp.l: Thou dost not mean to marry with a beggar?

sp.speaker: Mary.
sp.l: Unless he be a gentleman, and Bonvile
Is by his birth no less.

sp.speaker: Aud.
sp.l: Such only gentile are, that can maintain gentily.

sp.speaker: Mary.
sp.l: Why, should your state fail you,
Can it from you your honours take away?
Whilst your allegiance holds, what need you more,
You ever shall be noble although poor.

sp.speaker: Aud.
sp.l: They are noble that have nobles; gentle they
That appear such.

sp.speaker: Mary.
sp.l: Indeed so worldlings say:
But virtuous men prove they are only dear
That all their riches can about them bear.

div.stage: Sound: enter the King, Clinton, Bonvile, prince, Princess.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Is not Earl Chester
returned yet with an answer from the marshal?

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.l: Not yet my lord.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: For such contention we now scorn revenge,
We'll try the utmost of his patience now:
He would exceed our love, if it appear,
He will hold nothing for his King too dear.

sp.speaker: Aud.
sp.l: Earl Chester is returned.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Hast brought her Chester?

sp.speaker: Chest.
sp.l: Her whom her father the most fair esteems,
He hath sent by me, only with this request,
That if his free gift do not like your highness,
You'll send her back untouched to his embrace.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: I fear we shall not, she appears too fair,
So straight to part with: what is he would
Attempt such virgin-modesty to stain
By hopes of honour, flatteries, or constraint?
How do you like her? your opinions lords?

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.l: A beauteous lady, one that hath no peer
In the whole court.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Therefore I hold her precious.

sp.speaker: Princess.
sp.l: A fairer face in court whoever saw?
Her beauty, would become the name of Queen.

sp.speaker: Clin.
sp.l: One of more state or shape where shall we find?

sp.speaker: Aud.
sp.l: Her modesty doth do her beauty grace,
Both in her cheek have chused a sovereign seat.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: You have passed censure lady, now you're mine,
And by your father's free gift you are so,
To make, or mar; to keep or bestow.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.l: It glads me I am present to a King,
Whom I have always heard my father term
Royal in all things; virtuous, modest, chaste;
And to have one free attribute besides,
Which even the greatest emperor need not scorn,
Honest; to you if you be such my liege,
A virgin's love I prostrate, and a heart
That wishes you all goodness with the duty
of a true subject, and a noble father;
Then mighty prince report your subject noble,
Since all those virtues you receive in me.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Thou hast o'ercome us all; that thou hast termed us,
We'll strive to be, and to make good those attributes
Thou hast bestowed upon us, rise our Queen,
Thy virtue hath taken off the threatening edge
Of our intended hate: though thou art ours
Both by free gift and duty, which we challenge
As from a subject; though our power could stretch
To thy dishonour, we proclaim thee freed,
And in this grace thy father we exceed.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.l: The King in this shows honour. Prince's still
Should be the lords of their own appetites,
And cherish virtue.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Have I your applause?

sp.speaker: Bon.
sp.l: Your highness shows both royalty and judgement
In your fair choice.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Are your opinions so?

sp.speaker: Aud.
sp.l: Far be it mighty King we should distaste
Where you so well affect.

sp.speaker: Princess.
sp.l: For grace and feature
England affords not a more complete virgin.

sp.speaker: Clin.
sp.l: Were she not the marshal's daughter,
I'd term her worthy for my sovereign's bride.

sp.speaker: Chest.
sp.l: Ay that's the grief.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: This kiss then be the seal,
Thou art our Queen, and now art only mine.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.l: May I become your vassal and your handmaid,
Titles but equal to my humble birth:
But since your grace a higher title deigns,
Envy must needs obey where power compels.
Give expeditious order for the rites
Of these our present nuptials which shall be
Done with all state and due solemnity;
And marshal in this business thou shall find
Thyself defective, and not us unkind.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.l: Health to your highness.

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.l: From my sad master,
Your marshal once, now your dejected vassal,
And thus he bid me say: if the King deign
To grace my daughter with the style of Queen,
To give you then this casket which contains
A double dower; half of this mighty sum
He out of his revenues had afforded,
Had she been match but to a baron's bed;
But since your highness deigns her for your bride,
And his alliance scorns not to disdain,
He saith a double dower is due to you.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: He strives to exceed us still; this emulation
Begets our hate, and questions him of life.
This dower we take, his daughter entertain,
But him we never shall receive to grace.
Bear not from us so much as love or thanks:
We only strive in all our actions
To be held peerless for our courtesy
And royal bounty, which appears the worse,
Since he a subject would precede his prince:
And did we not his daughter dear love,
We'd send her back with scorn, and base neglect
But her we love, though him in heart despise,
Pay him that thanks for all his courtesies.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.l: In this employment I will strive to do
Th' office of a subject, and of servant too.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Since to that emulous lord we have sent our hate,
Come to our nuptials let's pass on in state.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: The humours of court, city, camp, and country I have traced, and in them can find no man, but money; all subscribe to this motto, malo pecuniam viro. O poverty, thou are esteemed a sin worse than whoredom, gluttony, extortion, or usury:
sp.l: And earthy gold, thou art preferred 'fore heaven.
Let but a poor man in a threadbare suit,
or ragged as I am, appear at court,
The fine-nosed courtiers will not sent him; no,
They shun the way as if they met the pest:
Or if he have a suit, it strikes them deaf,
They cannot hear of that side.

sp.speaker: Clown.
sp.p: Come to the city, the haberdasher will sooner call us block heads, than block us; come to the sempsters, unless we will give them money, we cannot enter into their bands: though we have the law of our sides, yet we may walk through Burchin-lane and be nonsuited: come barefoot to a shoemaker, though he be a constable, he will not put us into his stocks; though the girdler be my brother, yet he will not let his leather embrace me; come to the glover, his gloves are either so little that I cannot pluck them on, or so great that I cannot compass. And for the camp, there's honour cut out of the whole piece, but not a rag of money.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: The country hath alliance with the rest: my purpose is now I have so thoroughly made proof of the humours of men, I will next assay the dispositions of women, not of the choicest, but of those whom we call good wenches.

sp.speaker: Clown.
sp.p: Pray master if you go to a house of good fellowship, give me something to spend upon my cockatrice; if I have nothing about me, I shall never get in.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: There's for you sirrah; doth not the world wonder I should be so flush of money, and so bare in clothes? the reason of this I shall give account for hereafter: but to our purpose, here they say dwells my lady bawdy-face, here will we knock.

sp.speaker: Bawd.
sp.p: Who's there? what would you have? ha?

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: Sweet lady we would enter; nay by your leave.

sp.speaker: Bawd.
sp.p: Enter? where? here be no breaches for you to enter truly.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: And yet we are soldiers, and have ventured upon as hot service as this place affords any.

sp.speaker: Bawd.
sp.p:
Away you base companions, we have no breaches
for such tattered breeches, we have no patches to suit with your rags.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: Nay, pray give way.

sp.speaker: Bawd.
sp.p: Away you rogues, do you come to shake your rags here? do you think we can vent our ware without money you rascals? get you from my door you beggarly companions, or I'll wash you hence with hot scalding water.

sp.speaker: Clown.
sp.p: Nay I warrant her, wenches can afford her that at all times.

sp.speaker: Bawd.
sp.p: Do I keep house to entertain tatterdemalions with a pox, you will be gone?

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: We must forbear, the gallants are out of patience, stand aside.

sp.speaker: 1. Gent.
sp.p: I would fain go in, but I have spent all my money.

sp.speaker: 2. Gent.
sp.p: No matter, they shall not know so much till we get in, and then let me alone, I'll not out till I be fired out.

sp.speaker: 1. Gent.
sp.p: Then let's set a good face of the matter, by your leave lady.

sp.speaker: Bawd.
sp.p: You're welcome gentlemen.

sp.speaker: 1. Gent.
sp.p: What fellows be yond?

sp.speaker: Bawd.
sp.p: Two poor soldiers that came for an alms and please you, that stay for some reversions; there's none such come into my house I warrant you.

sp.speaker: 2. Gent.
sp.p: Save you sweet lady.

sp.speaker: Bawd.
sp.p: Where be those kitchenstuffs here, shall we have no attendants? show these gentlemen into a close room, with a standing bed in't, and a truckle too; you are welcome gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: 'Tis general thorough the world, each state esteems a man not what he is, but what he seems:
sp.l: The purest flesh raged can no entrance have,
But itch and all disease if it come brave,
Wide open stand the gates of lust and sin,
And those at which the wide world enters in.
sp.p:
Madam, to be short, I must have a wench, though I am ragged outward, I am rich inward: here's a brace of angels for
you, let me have a pretty wench, I'll be as bountiful to her.

sp.speaker: Bawd.
sp.p: Your worship's very heartily welcome: where's Sis? Where's Joyce? the best room in the house for the gentleman: call mistress Priscilla, and bid her keep the gentleman company.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: I'll make bold to enter.

sp.speaker: Bawd.
sp.p: Your worship's most lovingly welcome: let the gentleman have attendance, and clean linen it he need any; whither would you, you rogue?

sp.speaker: Clown.
sp.p: Marry I would after my master.

sp.speaker: Bawd.
sp.p: Thy master? why is yond raggamuffin able to keep a man?

sp.speaker: Clown.
sp.p: Ay that he is able to keep a man, and himself too.

sp.speaker: Bawd.
sp.p: Then that man must be able to pay for himself too, or else he may cool his heels without if his appetite be hot.

sp.speaker: Clown.
sp.p: Then shall I not go in?

sp.speaker: Bawd.
sp.p: No by my maidenhead shall you not, nor any such beggarly companion shall enter here, but he shall come thorough me too.

sp.speaker: Clown.
sp.p: No? what remedy? ha, ha; he that rings at a door with such a bell, and cannot enter? Well, if there be no remedy, I'll even stay without.

sp.speaker: Bawd.
sp.p: O me! is it you sir? and are so strong to stand at the door? Pray will you come near? your master is new gone in afore: lord, lord, that you would not enter without trusting! you were even as far out of my remembrance as one that I had never seen afore.

sp.speaker: Clown.
sp.p: I cannot blame you to forget me, for I think this be the first time of our meeting.

sp.speaker: Bawd.
sp.p: What would you have sir?

sp.speaker: Clown.
sp.p: Nothing as they say, but a congratulation for our first acquaintance. I have it here old bully bottom, I have it here.

sp.speaker: Bawd.
sp.p: I have it here too: nay, pray sir come in, I am loath to kiss at door, for fear my neighbours should see.

sp.speaker: Clown.
sp.l: Speak, shall you and I condog together?
I'll pay you to a hair.

sp.speaker: Bawd.
sp.p: Nay, I beseech you sir, come in: a gentleman, and stand at door? I'll lead the way, and you shall come behind.

sp.speaker: Clown.
sp.p: No, no; I will not salute you after the Italian fashion: I'll enter before.

sp.speaker: Bawd.
sp.p: Most lovingly, pray draw the latch sir.

div.stage: Enter the two gentlemen with the two wenches.

sp.speaker: 1. Gent.
sp.p: Nay faith sweet rogue thou shalt trust me for once.

sp.speaker: 1. Whore.
sp.p: Trust you? come up, canst thou pay the hackney for the hire of a horse, and think'st thou to breathe me upon trust?

sp.speaker: 1. Gen.
sp.p: Thou bid'st me come up, and shall I not ride?

sp.speaker: 1. Whore.
sp.p: Yes the gallows as soon.

sp.speaker: 2. Whore.
sp.p: A gentleman, and have no money? marry you make a most knightly offer.

sp.speaker: 2. Gent.
sp.p: How? to offer thee no money?

sp.speaker: 2. Whore.
sp.p: How can they offer that have none?

sp.speaker: 2. Gent.
sp.p: I'll either give thee ware or money, that's as good.

sp.speaker: 2. Whore.
sp.p: Ay but sir, I'll deal with no such chapmen.

sp.speaker: Bawd.
sp.p: What's the matter here? ha? can you not agree about the bargain?

sp.speaker: 1. Whore.
sp.p: Here's gallants would have us breathed, and forsooth they have no money.

sp.speaker: 2. Whore.
sp.p: They think belike, diet, lodging, ruffs, clothes, and holland-smocks can all be had without money, and a disease, if we should catch it, heaven bless us, can be cured without money.

sp.speaker: Bawd.
sp.p: That's fine i'faith: if my beds be shaken out of their joints, or my cords broken, must not the joiner and the rope-maker both have money? if my rags be rubbed out with your toes, can they be repaired without money? if my linen be fouled, can I pay my laundress without money? besides, we must have so something to maintain our broken windows I hope; the glazier will not mend them without money.

sp.speaker: 1. Gent.
sp.p: Come, come let's run a score for once.

sp.speaker: Bawd.
sp.p: You shall not score of my tally, out of my doors.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: Why shall we not be bosomed? have we paid, and must we not have wenches?

sp.speaker: Bawd.
sp.p: You shall have the choicest of my house gentlemen.

sp.speaker: 1. Gent.
sp.p: Who, those rascals?

sp.speaker: Bawd.
sp.p: They be rascals that have no money; those be gentlemen that have crowns; these are they that pay the joiner, the rope-maker, the upholster, the launderer, the glazier; will you get you out of my doors, or shall we scold you hence?

sp.speaker: Clown.
sp.p: That you shall never by thrusting them out of doors.

sp.speaker: 1. Gent.
sp.p: Who but a mad man would be so base as to be hired, much more to hire one of those bruitists, that make no difference betwixt a gentleman and a beggar, nay, I have seen enough to be soon entreated.

sp.speaker: 2. Gent.
sp.p: You shall not need to fear me, I am gone:
sp.l: He's passed before, nor will I stay behind;
I have seen enough to loathe all your sisterhood.

sp.speaker: Bawd.
sp.p: Marry farewell frost. Now sir, will you make your choice, and your man after?

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: I'll have both, these are mine.

sp.speaker: Clown.
sp.p: Go you then with your pair of whores, I'll go with this old scholar that first plied me.

sp.speaker: Bawd.
sp.p: I see thou lovest to go by water; come, shall we dally together? sit upon my knee my sweet boy, what money hast thou in thy purse? wilt thou bestow this upon me my sweet chick?

sp.speaker: Clown.
sp.p: I'll see what I shall have first for my money by your favour.

sp.speaker: 1. Whore.
sp.p: And shall I have this?

sp.speaker: 2. Whore.
sp.p: And I this?

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: Both these are mine, we are agreed then? But I am ashamed, being such a tattered rogue, to lie with two such fine gentlewomen; besides, to tell you truly, I am lousy.

sp.speaker: 1. Whore.
sp.p:
No matter, thou shalt have a clean shirt, and
but pay for the washing, and thy clothes shall in the mean time be cast into an oven.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: But I have a worse fault, my skin's not perfect; what should I say I am?

sp.speaker: 2. Whore.
sp.p: Itchy? O thou shalt have brimstone and butter.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: Worse than all these, my body is diseased, I shall infect yours.

sp.speaker: 1. Whore.
sp.p: If we come by any mischance, thou hast money to pay for the cure: come, shall's withdraw into the next chamber?

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.l: You are not women, you are devils both,
And that your dam; my body save in wars,
Is yet unscarred, nor shall it be with you.
Say the last lecher that embraced you here,
And folded in his arms your rottenness,
Had been all these, would you not all that filth
Vomit on me? or who would buy diseases,
And make his body for a spittle fit,
That may walk sound? I came to school you whore,
Not to corrupt you; for what need I that
When you are all corruption; be he lame,
Have he no nose, be all his body stung
With the French fly, with the sarpego dried:
Be he a lazar, or a leper, bring
Coin in his fist, he shall embrace your lust
Before the purest flesh that sues of trust.

sp.speaker: Bawd.
sp.p: What Diogenes have we here? I warrant the cynic himself said not so much when he was seen to come out of a bawdy house.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.l: He shamed not to come out, but held it sin
Not to be pardoned to be seen go in.
But I'll be modest: nay, nay, keep your gold
To cure those hot diseases you have got,
And being once clear, betake you to one man,
And study to be honest, that's my counsel:
You have brought many like you gentlemen
that jet in silks, to go thus ragged like us,
Which did they own our thoughts, these rags would change
To shine as we shall, though you think it strange.
Come, come, this house is infected, shall we go?

sp.speaker: Clown.
sp.p: Why sir, shall I have no sport for my money, but even a snatch and away?

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.l: Leave me, and leave me ever, and observe
This rule from me, where there is lodged a whore,
Think the plague's cross is set upon that door.

sp.speaker: Clown.
sp.p: Then lord have mercy upon us: where have we been?

div.stage: The clown goes learing away, and shaking his head.

sp.speaker: Bawd.
sp.p: Hist, hist; here's a railing companion indeed.

sp.speaker: 1. Whore.
sp.p: I know not what you call a railing companion: but such another discourse would make me go near to turn honest.

sp.speaker: Bawd.
sp.p: Nay, if you be in that mind, I'll send for your love: the plague in my house? the pox is as soon: I am sure there was never man yet that had lord have mercy upon us in his mind, that would ever enter here: nay will you go?

div.stage: Sound, enter the King, prince, Princess, all the lords, the Queen, etc.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Before you all I here acknowledge lords,
I never held me happy but in this
My virtuous choice, in having your applause,
Methinks I had the sweet consent of heaven.

sp.speaker: Princess.
sp.l: This noble lady, now my royal mother,
Hath by her love to you, regard to us,
And courteous affability to all,
Attained the general suffrage of the realm,

sp.speaker: Princess.
sp.l: Her modest carriage shall be rules to me,
her words instructions, her behaviour precepts,
Which I shall ever study to observe.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: I feel my body growing by the King,
And I am quick although he know it not;
Now comes my father's last injunction
To my remembrance, which I must fulfil,
Although a Queen, I am his daughter still.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Lords, and the rest forbear us till we call,
A chair first, and another for our Queen,
Some private conference we intend with her:
Now leave us.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: My fairest Isabella, the choice jewel
That I wear next my heart; I cannot hide
My love to thee, 'tis like the sun enveloped
In watery clouds, whose glory will break thorough,
And spite opposure, scorns to be concealed;
Saving one thing, ask what my kingdom yields.
And it is freely thine.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: What's that my lord?

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: I cannot speak it without some distaste
To thee my Queen, yet if thy heart be ours
Name it not to me.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: I am only yours.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Beg not thy father's free repeal to court,
And to those offices we have bestowed,
Save this, my kingdom, and what it contains,
Is thy wills subject.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: You are my King, and husband;
The first includes allegiance, the next duty,
Both these have power above a father's name,
Though as a daughter I could wish it done,
Yet since it stands against your royal pleasure,
I have no suit that way.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Thou now hast thrust thy hand into my bosom,
And we are one: thy beauty, o thy beauty!
Never was King blessed with so fair a wife.
I do not blame thy father to prefer
thee 'fore thy sister both in love and face,
Since Europe yields not one of equal grace:
Why smiles my love?

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: As knowing one so fair,
With whom my pale cheek never durst compare:
Had you but seen my sister, you would say,
To her the blushing coral should give way:
For her cheek stains it; lilies to her brow
Must yield their ivory whiteness, and allow
Themselves o'ercome. If e'er you saw the sky
When it was clearest, it never could come nigh
Her azure veins in colour; she's much clearer,
Ay, and her love much to my father dearer.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: We by our noble marshal made request
For the most fair, and her whom he best loved:
Durst he delude us?

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: What I speak is true,
So will yourself say when she comes in place.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Our love to thee shall not overcome that hate
We owe thy father, though thou beest our Queen.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: He keeps her as his treasure, locks her safe
Within his arms: he only minded me
As one he loved not, but thought merely lost.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Thou art lost indeed, for thou hast lost my heart,
Nor shalt thou keep it longer: all my love
Is swallowed in the spleen I bear thy father,
And in this deep disgrace put on his King,
Which we'll revenge.

div.stage: Enter prince, Princess, Chester, Clinton, Bonvile, and Audley.

sp.speaker: King.
