sp.l: It shall be thus:
Chester bear hence this lady to her father
As one unworthy us, with her that dower
The double dower he by his servant sent:
Thy tears nor knee shall once prevail with us.
As thou art loyal, without further language
Depart our presence, we'll not hear thee speak.

sp.speaker: Chest.
sp.l: What shall I further say?

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Command him on his life to send to court
His tother daughter, and at our first summons,
Lest we proclaim him traitor: this see done
On thy allegiance.

sp.speaker: Chest.
sp.l: Now the goal is ours.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: None dare to censure or examine this,
That we shall hold our friend, or of our blood:
Subjects that dare against their Kings contend,
Hurl themselves down whilst others hie ascend.

div.head: Actus quartus.
div.stage: Enter the marshal and his daughter Katherine,

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: I see the King is truly honourable:
All my disgraces and disparagements
He hath made good to me in this to Queen my child,
And which more glads me, with such ardency
He seems to affect her, and to hold her dear,
That nothing's valued, if compared with her.
Now heaven whilst thou this second happiness
And bliss wilt lend me, I shall still grow great
In my content, opinion, and my fate,
In spite of whisperers, and court-flatterers.

sp.speaker: Kath.
sp.l: Had you best loved my sister, and less me,
I had been Queen before her; but she ventured
For her preferment, therefore 'tis her due;
Out of our fears and loves her honours grew.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Whilst I may keep thy beauty in mine eye,
And with her new raised fortunes fill mine ear,
I second none in bliss; she's my court comfort,
Thou my home happiness: in these two blessed,
Heaven hath enriched me with a crown of rest.

sp.speaker: Kath.
sp.l: Nor do I cover greater royalties
Than to enjoy your presence, and your love,
the best of these I prize above all fortunes,
Nor would I change them for my sister's state.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Her beauty and her virtues mixed, have won
The King my sovereign to be termed my son.

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.l: Earl Chester, with the Queen your princely daughter
Are without train alighted at the gate,
And by this entered.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Thou hast troubled me,
And with a thousand thoughts at once perplexed
My affrighted heart: admit them; soft, not yet;
What might this mean? my daughter in the charge
Of him that is my greatest opposite,
And without train, such as becomes a Queen?
More tempest towards Kate? from which sweet child,
If I may kept thee, may it on my head
Pour all his wrath, even till it strike me dead.

sp.speaker: Kath.
sp.l: Rather, my lord, your royal life to free,
All his stern fury let him shower on me.

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.l: My lord shall I admit them?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Prithee stay,
Fate threatens us, I would devise a means
To shun it if we might: thou shalt withdraw,
And not be seen; something we must devise
To guard ourselves, and stand our opposites:
Go keep your chamber, now let Chester in.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.l: I shall my lord.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: My loyalty for me, that keep me still;
A tower of safety, and a shield 'gainst fate.

div.stage: Enter the servant ushering Chester and the Queen.

sp.speaker: Chest.
sp.l: The King thy daughter hath in scorn sent back.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Pause there, and as y' are noble answer me
Ere you proceed but to one question.

sp.speaker: Chest.
sp.l: Propound it.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Whence might this distaste arise?
From any loose demeanour wanton carriage,
Spouse-breach, or disobedience in my daughter?
If so, I'll not receive her, she's not mine.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: That let mine enemy speak, for in this kind
I would be taxed by such.

sp.speaker: Chest.
sp.l: Upon my soul
There is no guilt in her.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Be't but his humour,
Thou'rt welcome, both my daughter and my Queen;
In this my palace thou shalt reign alone,
I'll keep thy state, and make these arms thy throne:
Whilst thou art chaste, thy style with thee shall stay,
And reign, though none but I and mine obey.
What can you further speak?

sp.speaker: Chest.
sp.l: Her double dower
The King returns thee.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: We accept it, see,
It shall maintain her port even with her name,
Being my King's wife, so will I love his grace,
She shall not want, will double this maintain her.

sp.speaker: Chest.
sp.l: Being thus discharged of her, I from the King
Command thee send thy fairer girl to court,
She that's at home, with her to act his pleasure.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Sir, you were sent to challenge, not to kill;
These are not threats, but blows, they wound, they wound.

sp.speaker: Chest.
sp.l: If treason's imputation thou wilt shun,
And not incur the forfeit of thy life,
Let the Kings will take place.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: You have my offices,
Would you had now my grief; but that alone
I must endure: would thou hadst both, or none.
Sentence of death when it is mildly spoke,
Halt promises life; but when your doom you mix
With such rough threats, what is't but twice to kill?
You tyrannize Earl Chester.

sp.speaker: Chest.
sp.l: Will you send her?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: That you shall know anon. Tell me my Queen,
How grew this quarrel between the King and thee?

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: By you was never lady more beloved,
or wife more constant than I was to him:
Have you forgotten your charge, when I perceived
Myself so grown, I could no longer hide
My greatness, I began to speak the beauties
Of my fair sister, and how much she excelled,
And that you sent me thither as a jest,
That she was fairest, and you loved her best?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Enough; thou'rt sure with child, and near thy time

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: Nothing more sure.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Then that from hence shall grow
A salve for all our late indignities:
Pray do my humble duty to the King.
And thus excuse me, that my daughter's sick,
Crazed, and weak, and that her native beauty
Is much decayed; and should she travel now,
Before recovered, 'twould engage her life
To too much danger: when she hath ability
And strength to journey, I will send her safe
Unto my King; this as I am a subject,
And loyal to his highness.

sp.speaker: Chest.
sp.l: Your excuse
Hath ground from love and reason:
This your answer I shall return to the King.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: With all my thanks:
That since my daughter doth distaste his bed,
He hath sent her back, and home to me her father,
His pleasure I withstand not, but return
My zeal, and these do not forget I pray.

sp.speaker: Chest.
sp.p: I shall your words have perfect, and repeat them unto the King.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: I should disgrace her beauty
To send it maimed and waning; but when she
Attains her perfectness, then shall appear
The brightest star fixed in your courtly sphere.

sp.speaker: Chest.
sp.l: The King shall know as much.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: It is my purpose,
All my attempts to this one head to draw,
once more in courtesies to o'ercome the King.
Come beauteous Queen, and thy fair sister cheer,
Whom this sad news will both amaze and fear.

div.stage: Enter Bonvile in all his bravery, and his man in a new livery.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: Sirrah, are all my lands out of mortgage, and my deeds redeemed?

sp.speaker: Clown.
sp.p: I cannot tell that sir; but we have had whole chest-fulls of writings brought home to our house.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.l: Why then 'tis done, I am possessed again
Of all my father's ancient revenues.

sp.speaker: Clown.
sp.p: But how came you by all this money to buy these new suits? methinks we are not the men we were.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: Questionless that;. for now those that before despised us, and our company, at meeting give us the bonjour.
sp.l: O heaven, thou ever art virtue's sole patron,
And wilt not let it sink: all my known fortunes
I had engaged at home, or spent abroad:
But in the wars, when I was held quite bankrupt
Of all good hap, it was my chance to quarter
In such a house when we had sacked a town,
That yielded me inestimable store
Of gold and jewels, those I kept till now
Unknown to any, pleading poverty,
Only to try the humour of my friends;
Which I have proved, and now know how to find
Fixed upon wealth, to want unnatural.

sp.speaker: Clown.
sp.p: See sir, yonder are my old fellows, match and touch box; I do not think but they come to offer their service to you.

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: Save thee noble captain, hearing of thy good fortunes, and advancement, I am come to offer myself to be partaker of the same, and to follow thee in the same colours that thou hast suited the rest of thy servants.

sp.speaker: Clown.
sp.p: God-a-mercy horse, you shall not stand to my livery.

sp.speaker: Match
sp.p: You see our old clothes stick by us still, good captain see us new moulded.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.l: You are flies, away; they that my winter fled,
Shall not my summer taste: they only merit
A happy harbour, that through stormy seas
Hazard their barks, not they that sail with ease.
You taste none of my fortunes.

sp.speaker: Clown.
sp.p: Corporal, you see this livery? if you had stayed by it, we had been both cut out of a piece: match, if you had not left us, you had been one of this guard: go, away, betake you to the end of the town; let me find you between woods close-stile and Islington, with will it please your worship to bestow the price of two cans upon a poor soldier, that hath served in the face of the sultan, and so forth, apage, away, I scorn to be fellow to any that will leave their masters in adversity: if he entertain you, he shall turn away me, that's certain.

sp.speaker: Match.
sp.p: Then good your worship bestow something upon a poor soldier, I protest â€”

sp.speaker: Clown.
sp.p: Lo, I have taught him his lesson already; I knew where I should have you?

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: There's first to make you beggars; for to that all such must come that leave their masters poor. Begun, and never let me see you more.

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: God be with you good captain: come match, let us betake us to our rendezvous at some out end of the city.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.l: He makes a beggar first that first relieves him;
Not usurers make more beggars where they live,
Than charitable men that use to give.

sp.speaker: Clown.
sp.l: Here comes a lord.

sp.speaker: Clin.
sp.l: I am glad to see you sir.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.l: You know me now? your worship's wondrous wise,
You could not know me in my last disguise.

sp.speaker: Clin.
sp.l: Lord God you were so changed.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.l: So am I now
From what I was of late: you can allow
This habit well, but put my tother on,
No congee then, your lordship must be gone.
You are my summer-friend.

sp.speaker: Bonu.
sp.l: Cousin, well met.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.l: You should have said well found
For I was lost but late, dead, under ground
Our kindred was: when I redeemed my land,
They both revived, and both before you stand,

sp.speaker: Bon.
sp.l: Well, well, I know you now.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.l: And why not then?
I am the same without all difference; when
You saw me last, I was as rich, as good,
Have no additions since of name, or blood;
Only because I wore a threadbare suit,
I was not worthy of a poor salute.
A few good clothes put on with small ado,
Purchase your knowledge, and your kindred too.
You are my silken uncle: o my lord,

div.l: You are not in haste now?

sp.speaker: Aud.
sp.l: I have time to stay,
To ask you how you do, being glad to hear
Of your good fortune, your repurchased lands,
And state much amplified.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.l: All this is true;
Ay but my lord, let me examine you:
Remember you a contract that once passed
Betwixt me and your daughter? here she stands.

sp.speaker: Aud.
sp.l: Sir, since you did unmortgage all your means,
It came into my thoughts; trust me, before
I could not call't to mind.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.l: O men's weak strength,
That aim at worlds, when they but their mere length
Must at their end enjoy: thou then art mine,
Of all that I have proved in poverty,
The only test of virtue: what are these?
Though they be lords, but worldlings, men all earth.
Thou art above them; virtuous, that's divine;
Only thy heart is noble, therefore mine.

sp.speaker: Mary.
sp.l: And to be yours is to be what I wish;
You were to me as welcome in your rags,
As in these silks. I never did examine
The out side of a man, but I begin
To censure first of that which grows within.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.l: Only for that I love thee: these are lords
That have bought titles. Men may merchandise
Wares, ay, and traffic all commodities
From sea to sea, ay and from shore to shore,
But in my thoughts, of all things that are sold,
'Tis pity honour should be bought for gold.
It cuts off all desert.

sp.speaker: Clown.
sp.p: Master, who's here? mine host of the ordinary?

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: Your business sir? what by petition?

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p: Fallen to a little decay by trusting, and knowing your worship ever a bountiful young gentleman, I make bold to make my wants first known to you.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: Pray what's your suit?

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p: Only for a cast suit, or some small remuneration.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: And thou shalt have the suit I last put off: fetch it me cock.

sp.speaker: Cock.
sp.p: I shall sir.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: Fallen to decay? I'll fit you in your kind.

sp.speaker: Cock.
sp.p: I have a suit to you sir, and this it is.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.l: In this suit came I to thine ordinary,
In this thou wouldst have thrust me out of doors,
Therefore with this that then proclaimed me poor,
I'll salve thy wants, nor will I give thee more.
Base worldlings, that despise all such as need;
Who to the needy beggar are still dumb,
Not knowing unto what themselves may come.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p: I have a cold suit on't if I be forced to wear it in winter. I bid your worship farewell.

sp.speaker: Clown.
sp.p: So should all that keep ordinaries, bid their guests farewell, though their entertainment be never so ill. Well sir, I take you but for an ordinary fellow, and so I leave you. Master, who will not say that you are a brave fellow, and a most noble captain, that with a word or two can discomfit an host.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.l: I know you, therefore know to rate your worths
Both to their height and depth, their true dimensions
I understand; for I have tried them all:
But thou art of another element,
A mirror of thy sex, that canst distinguish
Virtue from wealth, thee as my own I elect,
And these according to themselves despise.
A courtier henceforth I myself profess,
And thee my wife, thou hast deserved no less.

div.stage: Enter the King, the prince, and the Princess, and Chester.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: No news yet from our marshal? we three months
Have stayed his leisure, but receive not yet
That daughter we sent for.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.l: She peradventure
Hath not her strength recovered, or her beauty
Lost by her sickness, to the full regained.

sp.speaker: Chest.
sp.l: Upon my life my lord, when she is perfect,
And hath received her full ability,
She shall attend your pleasure.

sp.speaker: Princess.
sp.l: But your Queen,
That virtuous lady, when I think on her,
I can but grieve at her dejectedness.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Heaven knows I love her above all the world,
And but her father, this contends with us
When we in all our actions strive to exceed:
We could not brook her absence half so long.
But we will try his patience to the full.

div.stage: Enter Bonvile, Audley, captain, Clinton, marry the clown.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.l: My prostrate duty to the King my master
I here present.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.l: This is the gentleman
Commended for his valour in your wars,
Whose ruined fortunes I made suit to raise:
I would entreat your highness to respect him.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: All his proceedings we partake at large,
know both his fall and height; we shall regard him
Even with his worth: be near us, of our chamber.
Sir, we shall use your wisdom, and prefer it
According to your worth. Be this your hope
We know you.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.l: Only in that I am happy.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.l: Health to your majesty.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Whence?

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.l: From my master,
The poorest subject that your land contains,
Rich only in his truth and loyalty.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Speak, hath he sent his daughter?

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.l: Yes my liege,
He hath sent his daughters, please you rest satisfied,
And patiently peruse what he hath sent.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: We are full of expectations, pray admit
Those presents that he means to greet us with.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.l: You shall my lord.

div.stage: Sound, enter with two gentlemen-ushers before them, the Queen crowned, her sister to attend her as her waiting-maid, with a train.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.l: Your Queen and wife crowned with a wreath of gold
Of his own charge, with that this double dower
Doubled again, and guarded with this train
Of gentlewomen according to her state,
My lord presents you: this his younger daughter,
He hath bestowed a handmaid to your Queen,
A place that may become her, were she child
Unto your greatest peer; had he had more,
More had he sent; these worthless as they be,
He humbly craves you would receive by me.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: His bounty hath no limit, but my Queen!
Her bright aspect so much persuades with me,
It charms me more than his humility.
Arise in grace, and sweet, forget your wrong.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: My joys unspeakable can find no tongue
To express my true heart's meaning.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Beauteous maid,
You are our sister, and that royal title
From all disgrace your freedom shall proclaim.

sp.speaker: Kath.
sp.l: I find your grace the same my noble father
Hath still reported you; royal in all,
By whom the virtuous rise, th' th'ignoble fall.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.l: I have not seen a lady more complete;
Her modesty and beauty, both are matchless.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Am I a King, and must be exceeded still?
Or shall a subject say that we can owe?
His bounty we will equal, and exceed;
We have power to better what in him's but well.
Your free opinions lords, is not this lady
The fairer of the twain? how durst our subject
Than dally with us in that high design?

sp.speaker: Chest.
sp.l: With pardon of the Queen, she's paralleled
By her fair sister.

sp.speaker: Clin.
sp.l: Were my censure free,
I durst say bettered.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.l: Were it put to me,
I should avow she, not the Queen alone
Excels in grace: but all that I have seen â€”

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Dost love her?

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.l: As my honour, or my life.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Her whom thou so much praisest, take to wise.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.l: You bless my youth.

sp.speaker: Kate.
sp.l: And strive to eternize me.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: Nor in this joy have I the meanest part,
Now doth your grace your inward love express
To me, and mine.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: I never meant thee less:
Thy sister and thy daughter freely embrace,
That next thee hath our kingdom's second place,
How say you lords, have we requited well
Our subjects bounty? are we in his debt?

sp.speaker: Aud.
sp.l: Your highness is in courtesy invincible.

sp.speaker: Bonu.
sp.l: And bountiful beyond comparison.

sp.speaker: Chest.
sp.l: This must not hold, prevention out of hand,
for if the marshal rise, we stand not long.

sp.speaker: Clin.
sp.l: Our wits must then to work.

sp.speaker: Chest.
sp.l: They must of force.
This is not that to which our fortunes trust.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Let then our subject know his King hath power
To vanquish him in all degrees of honour,
And he must now confess himself excelled:
With what can heaven or earth his want supply
To equal this our latest courtesy?
We have the day, we rise, and he must fall
As one subdued.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.l: His highness knows not all,
One special gift he hath reserved in store,
May happily make your grace contend no more.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: No sir? think you your master will yet yield?
And leave to us the honour of the day?
I wish him here but this last sight to see,
To make him us acknowledge.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.l: On my knee
One boon I have to beg.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Speak, let me know
Thy utmost suit.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.l: My noble master stays
Not far from court, and durst he be so ambitious
As but to appear before you, and present you
With a rich gift exceeding all have passed,
The only perfect token of his zeal,
He would himself perpetually hold vanquished
In all degrees of love and courtesy.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: For our Queen's love, and our fair daughter's sake,
We do not much care if we grant him that.
Admit him, and his presence urge with speed;
Well may he imitate, but not exceed.

sp.speaker: Chest.
sp.l: I fear our fall: if once the marshal rise,
Down, down must we.

sp.speaker: Clin.
sp.l: Therefore devise some plot
His favour to prevent.

sp.speaker: Chest.
sp.l: Leave it to me.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Lords, we are proud of this our unity,
Double alliance, of our sons fair choice,
Since 'tis applauded by your general voice;
The rather since so matchless is our grace,
That force perforce our subject must give place.

div.stage: Enter the marshal, with a rich cradle born after him by two servants.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Not to contend, but to express a duty
Of zeal and homage I present your grace
With a rich jewel, which can only value
These royal honours to my daughter's done.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Value our bounty? shouldst thou sell thyself
Even to thy skin, thou couldst not rate it truly.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: My liege, I cannot, but in lieu and part,
Though not in satisfaction, I make bold
To tender you this present.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: What's the project?
Here's cost and art, and amply both expressed,
I have not viewed the like.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.l: 'Tis wondrous rare,
I have not seen a model richlier framed.

sp.speaker: Princess.
sp.l: Or for the quantity better contrived:
This lord in all his actions is still noble,
Exceeding all requital.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: 'Tis a brave outside.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: This that you see my lord is nothing yet;
More than its worth it hath commended been:
This is the case, the jewel lies within,
Pleaseth your grace t'unveil it.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Yes, I will:
But ere I open it my lord, I doubt
The wealth within not equals that without.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: What have we here?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: A jewel I should rate,
were it mine own, above your crown and sceptre,

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: A child?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: A prince, one of your royal blood:
Behold him King, my grandchild, and thy son,
Truly descended from thy Queen and thee,
The image of thyself.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: How can this be?

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: My royal liege and husband, view him well,
If your own favour you can call to mind,
Behold it in this infant, limned to'th life;
He's yours and mine, no kindred can be nearer.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: To this rich jewel I hold nothing equal,
I know thee virtuous, and thy father loyal;
But should I doubt both, yet this royal infant
Hath such affection in my heart impressed,
That it assures him mine: my noble subject,
Thou hast at length o'ercome me, and I now
Shall ever, ever hold me vanquished.
Hadst thou sought earth or sea, and from them both
Extracted that which was most precious held,
Thou nothing couldst have found to equal this,
This, the mixed image of my Queen and me;
Here then shall all my emulation end,
O'ercome by thee our subject, and our friend.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Your vassal, and your servant, that have striven
Only to love you, and your royal favours:
Not to requite, for that I never can;
But to acknowledge, and in what I may
To express my gratitude.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Thine is the conquest:
But shall I gi't o'er thus? 'tis in my head
How I this lost days honour shall regain,
A gift as great as rich I have in store,
With which to gratify our subjects' love,
And of a value unrequitable:
Thou hast given me a grandchild, and a son,
A royal infant, and to me most dear,
yet to surpass thee in this emulous strife,
I give thee here a daughter and a wife.
Now must thou needs confess the conquest won
By me thy King, thy father, and thy son.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Your father, son, and subject quite surpassed,
Yields himself vanquished and o'ercome at length.

sp.speaker: Princess.
sp.l: You have not my consent yet.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Madam, no;
The King doth this, his bounty to express.
Your love is to yourself, and therefore free,
Bestow it where you please.

sp.speaker: Princess.
sp.l: Why then on thee:
He that the father doth so much respect,
Should not methinks the daughter's love despise.
'Tis good for maids take husbands when they may.
Heaven knows how long we may be forced to stay.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Now lords, these nuptials we will solemnize
In all high state, in which we will include
Yours noble Bonvile, and with masks and revels
Sport out the tedious nights, each hand his bride
Doubly by us from either part allied.

sp.speaker: Cock.
sp.p:
Why this is as it should be; now do I smell courtier already, I feel the soldier steal out of me by degrees, for soldier and courtier can hardly dwell both together in one bosom. I have a kind of fawning humour creeping upon me as soon as I but looked into the ourt-gate; and now could I take a bribe, if any would be so foolish to gi't me. Now farewell gunpowder, I must change thee into damask-powder; for if I offer but to smell like a soldier, the courtiers will stop their noses when they pass by me. My cask I must change to a cap and a feather, my bandillero to a scarf to hang my sword in, and indeed, fashion myself wholly to the humours of the time. My piece I must alter to a poynado, and my pike to a pickadevant: only this is my comfort, that our provant will be better here in the court than in the camp: there we did use to lie
hard, and seldom: here I must practise to lie extremely, and often: but whilst I am trifling here, I shall lose the fight of the solemnity: the prince is married, and the marshal's married, and my master's married, there will be simple doings at night. Well, I must hence, for I believe, the King, the Queen, and the rest of the lords will use this place for their revels. Dixi.

div.head: Actus quintus.

sp.speaker: Clin.
sp.l: And why so sad my lord?

sp.speaker: Chest.
sp.l: I am all dulness,
There's no life in me, I have lost my spirit,
And fluence of my brain: observe you not
In what a height you fellow now resides
That was so late dejected; trebly grafted
Into the royal blood? what can succeed,
But that we all our honours must resign,
And he of them be repossessed again?

sp.speaker: Clin.
sp.l: The marriages indeed are celebrated.

sp.speaker: Chest.
sp.l: And they have all our pointed stratagems
Turned back upon ourselves.

sp.speaker: Clin.
sp.l: What, no prevention?

sp.speaker: Chest.
sp.l: His bases are so fixed he cannot shrink,
Being so many ways engraft and planted
In the King's blood: but our supporters stand
As shaked with earthquakes, or else built on sand.

sp.speaker: Aud.
sp.l: My lords attend the King, and clear this chamber,
For this nights revels 'tis the place prepared.

sp.speaker: Bon.
sp.l: Your duties lords, the king's upon his entrance.

div.stage: Enter the King, the Queen, the prince, his wife, the marshal and the Princess.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Ay, so 'tmust be, each man hand his own:
For I am where I love; we are even coupled,
some music then.

sp.speaker: Princess.
sp.l: Here's one falls off from me.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: How now my lord, dejected in your looks?
Or doth our sports distaste you?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Pardon me,
I cannot dance my liege.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: You can look on:
My lord, you take his place, we'll have a measure,
And I will lead it; bid the music strike.

div.stage: A measure: in the midst the marshal goes discontented away.
div.l: So, well done ladies: but we miss the husband
To our fair daughter, what's become of him?

sp.speaker: Chest.
sp.l: Gone discontented hence.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: What might this mean?
Doth he distaste his bride, or envy us
That are degreed above him? where's our Queen?

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: My liege?

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: You shall unto him instantly,
Attended with a beauteous train of ladies,
And to his chamber bear his princely bride.
Bonvile, take you her royal dower along,
You shall receive it of our treasurer.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.l: I shall my lord.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Usher the Queen and ladies, be their guide,
That done, each one to bed with his fair bride.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: I am so high, that when I look but down,
To see how far the earth is under me,
It quakes my body, and quite chills my blood:
And in my fear although I stand secure,
I am like him that falls. I but a subject,
And married to the daughter of the King,
Though some may think me happy in this match,
To me 'tis fearful: who would have a wife
Above him in command, to embrace with awe,
Whom to displease, is to distaste the King?
It is to have a mistress, not a wife,
A Queen, and not a subject's bedfellow.
State I could wish abroad to crown my head,
But never yet loved empire in my bed.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.l: The Queen your daughter with your princely bride,
And other ladies, make way towards your chamber.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: 'Tis open to receive them, pray them in.

div.stage: Enter Bonvile, the Queen, the Princess, etc.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: My lord the King commends his love to you
In your fair bride, whom royally conducted
He hath sent to be the partner of your bed.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Whom we receive in the arms of gratitude,
Duty to him, and nuptial love to her.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.l: 'Tis well they brought me, trust me my dear lord,
I should have scarce had face to have come myself;
But yet their boldness mixed with mine together,
Makes me to venture I yet scarce know whither.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: 'Tis to our nuptial bed.

sp.speaker: Princess.
sp.l: Ay so they say,
But unto me it is a patch unknown;
Yet that which cheers me, I shall do no more
Than those, and such as I, have done before.
Sure 'tis a thing that must, though without skill,
Even when you please, I am ready for your will.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.l: With her the King hath sent this princely dower,
In which his love and bounty he commends.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: You are noble sir, and honour waits on you
To crown your future fortunes: for that casket,
Her beauty and her birth are dower sufficient
For me a subject.
I cannot think so much good to my King
As I am owing for her single self:
Then with all duty pray return that sum.
Her dower is in herself, and that I'll keep
Which in these loyal all arms this night shall sleep:
That is the Kings, with that this jewel too,
I think her cheap bought at that easy rate;
My second duty in that gift commend,
Were I worth more, more I have will to send.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.l: An emperor cannot show more royalty
Than this brave peer, he's all magnificent:
I shall with the best eloquence I have,
Make known your thoughts.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: To all at once good night:
Save this my beauteous bride, no wealth I prize,
That hath my heart took captive in her eyes.
Lights for the Queen and ladies, night grows old,
I count my virtue treasure, not my gold.

div.stage: Enter Clinton to the Earl Chester in his study.

sp.speaker: Clin.
sp.l: What not at rest my lord?

sp.speaker: Chest.
sp.l: Why who can sleep
That hath a labouring brain, and sees from far
So many storms and tempests threaten him?
It is not in my element to do't.

sp.speaker: Clin.
sp.l: Find you no project yet how to remove him?

sp.speaker: Chest.
sp.l: None, none, and therefore can I find no rest.

sp.speaker: Clin.
sp.l: It grows towards day.

sp.speaker: Chest.
sp.l: That day is night to me,
Whilst you sun shines: I had this even some conference
In private with the King, in which I urged
The marshal's discontent, withal inferred,
That by his look the Princess he despised:
The King changed face: and could we second this
By any new conjecture, there were hope.
To draw him in displeasure.

sp.speaker: Clin.
sp.l: Watch advantage,
And as you find the humour of the King,
Work it unto the marshal's deep disgrace:
But soft the prince.

sp.speaker: Kath.
sp.l: So early up, how did you like your rest?

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.l: I found my most rest in my most unrest;
A little sleep serves a new married man:
the first night of his brydalls I have made you
A woman of a maid.

sp.speaker: Kath.
sp.l: You were up
Both late and early.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.l: Why you were abroad
Before the sun was up, and the most wise
Do say 'tis healthful still betimes to rise.
Good day.

sp.speaker: Chest.
sp.l: In one, ten thousand.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.l: Lords, you have not seen
The King today? it was his custom ever
Still to be stirring early with the sun;
But here's his majesty.

div.stage: Enter captain and the King, Audley, and Bonvile.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Not all your smooth and cunning oratory
Can colour so his pride, but we esteem him
A flattering traitor, one that scorns our love,
And in disdain sent back our daughter's dower:
Your judgement lords?

sp.speaker: Chest.
sp.l: Hath he refused the Princess?

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: No; but her dower sent back, and insolently;
Her whom we gave, he with a gift would buy,
A jewel; shall we merchandise our daughter,
As one not able to bestow her nobly,
But that our poverty must force us sell her?

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.l: Your highness much mispriseth his intent,
For he had no such thought.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: We know his pride,
Which his ambition can no longer shadow.

sp.speaker: Chest.
sp.l: Your highness might do well to call in question
His insolence and to arraign him fort.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Be you his judges Bonvile, Audley, you:
Command him straight on his allegiance,
To make appearance, and to answer us
Before our lords of his contempt and scorn.

sp.speaker: Prince
sp.l: Shall we command him hither?

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: From his bed,
And if convicted, he shall surely pay for't.

sp.speaker: Aud.
sp.l: We shall my lord.

sp.speaker: Chest.
sp.l: Arraign him on the sudden, ere it proved;
Le him not dream upon evasive shifts,
But take him unprepared.

sp.speaker: Clin.
sp.l: Shall we command
A bar, and call a jury of his peers,
Whilst Chester, that enjoys the place of marshal,
Objects such allegations 'gainst his life,
As he hath drawn out of his rude demeanour?

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: It shall be so; a bar, and instantly
We will ourself in person hear him speak,
And see what just excuse he can produce
For his contempt.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.l: My gracious lord and father,
What he hath done to you, proceeds of honour,
Not of disdain, or scorn; he's truly noble:
And if a regal bounty be a sin
In any subject, he's only guilty
Of that true virtue.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.l: Saw your majesty
With what an humble zeal, and prostrate love
He did retender your fair daughter's dower,
You would not his intent thus misreceive.

sp.speaker: Chest.
sp.l: 'Tis humble pride, and mere hypocrisy
To blind the King, 'tis but ambitious zeal,
And a dissembling cunning to aspire.

sp.speaker: Kath.
sp.l: My father called in question for his life?
O let not me a sad spectator be
Of such a dismal object.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.l: Nor will I,
But leave them to their hated cruelty.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: This is no place for ladies, we allow
Her absence; of the rest let none depart,
Till we have searched the cunning of his heart.

div.stage: A bar set out, the King and Chester, with Clinton, and the prince, and captain take their seats, Audley and Bonvile bring him to the bar as out of his bed, then take their seats.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: A bar, a judgement seat, and jury set?
Yet cannot all this daunt our innocence.

sp.speaker: Chest.
sp.l: You have disloyally sought to exceed
The King your sovereign, and his royal deeds
To blemish, which your fellow peers thus construe,
That strengthened by th'alliance of the King,
And better armed by the people's love,
You may prove dangerous.
In policy of state to quench the sparks
Before they grow to flame, and top your height,
Before your spacious branches spread too far,
What to this general motion can you say,
Before we tax you with particulars?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: With reverence to the state 'fore which I stand,
That you my lord of Chester appear shallow,
To think my actions can disgrace the Kings,
As if the luster of a petty star
Should with the moon compare: alas, my deeds
Conferred with his, are like a candle's light
To outshine the midday's glory. Can the King
The glorious mirror of all gratitude,
Condemn that virtue in another's bosom,
Which in his own shines so transparently?
O pardon me, mere virtue is my end,
Whose pitch the King doth many times transcend.

sp.speaker: Clin.
sp.l: To tax you more succinctly, you have first
Abused the King in sending to the court
Your daughter less fair, and the least beloved.

sp.speaker: Aud.
sp.l: And that includes contempt most barbarous,
Which you in that unsubject-like expressed:
Your former emulations we omit.
As things that may find tolerable excuse,
And are indeed not matters capital:
but to the best and greatest, when the King,
Out of his bounty and magnificence
Vouchsafed to style thee with the name of son,
Being but a subject, with contorted brows
And looks of scorn you took his courtesy,
And in contempt sent back the Princess dower.

sp.speaker: Chest.
sp.l: Most true; a grounded proposition
To question you of life.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: My life my lords?
It pleases me, that the King in person deigns
To grace my cause with his majestic ear:
You plead for me in this, and speak my excuse.
I have but two in all,
He sent for one, and he received them both,
With them a sweet and lovely prince to boot;
Whoever lost, I am sure the King hath won
At once, a wife, a daughter, and a son.

sp.speaker: Bonu.
sp.l: 'Tis true my lord, we all can witness it.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: He that my discontent objects to me,
With the fair Princess speaks uncertainly.
The man judicious such for fools allows,
As have their inward hearts drawn in their brows:
Is there in all that bench a man so honest
That can in this be discontent with me?
I charge you all; those favours I receive
From his high majesty, I swallow not
With greedy appetite, perhaps like you:
When I am graced, it comes with awe and fear,
Lest I offend that prince that holds me dear.
That for my brow.

sp.speaker: Chest.
sp.l: But for your scornful sending
Of the fair Princess dower back to th' King,
How can you answer that?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Why Chester thus:
I am a man, though subject; if the meanest
Lord o'er his wife; why should that privilege
Be only barred me? should I wive an empress,
and take her dowerless, should we love, or hate,
In that my bounty equals her estate.
Witness that judge above you, I esteem
The Princess dear, and yet married her
But as my wife, for which I am infinitely
Bound to the King: why should I grow engaged
Above my power, since this my lords you know,
The less we run in debt, the less we owe.
Give me my thoughts, and score you on I pray,
I wish no more than I have means to pay.

sp.speaker: Chest.
sp.l: Shall we my lord his actions censure freely?

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: And sentence them.

sp.speaker: Aud.
sp.l: A Persian history
I read of late, how the great sophy once
Flying a noble falcon at the Herne,
In comes by chance an eagle sousing by,
Which when the hawk espies, leaves her first game,
And boldly ventures on the King of birds;
Long tugged they in the air, till at the length
The falcon better breathed, seized on the eagle,
And struck it dead: the barons praised the bird,
And for her courage she was peerless held.
The emperor, after some deliberate thoughts,
Made him no less: he caused a crown of gold
To be new framed, and fitted to her head
In honour of her courage: then the bird
With great applause was to the marketplace
In tri triumph born, where, when her utmost worth
Had been proclaimed, the common executioner
First by the Kings command took off her crown,
And after with a sword struck off her head,
As one no better than a noble traitor
Unto the King of birds.

sp.speaker: Chest.
sp.l: This use we make
From this your ancient Persian history,
That you a noble and a courteous peer,
Praised for your hospital virtues and high bounty,
shall be first crowned with laurel to your worth:
But since you durst against your sovereign
Oppose yourself, you by your pride misled,
Shall as a noble traitor lose your head.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: That sentence we confirm, and it shall stand
Irrevocable by our straight command.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: I am glad my liege I have a life yet left,
In which to show my bounty, even in that
I will be liberal, and spend it for you;
Take it, 'tis the last jewel that I have,
In lieu of which o grant me but a grave.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: A laurel wreath, a scaffold, and a block,
Ourself will see the execution done:
Only thy life is ours, thy goods are free.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: My lord, you are the life of courtesy,
And you are kind unto me above measure,
To give away what might enrich yourself.
Since they are mine, I will bestow them thus:
The best of those that were so late but yours,
My jewels, ay, by will, restore you back,
You shall receive them separate from the rest:
To you the King's son, and by marriage mine,
On you I will bestow my armoury,
Stables of horse, and weapons for the wars,
I know you love a soldier: to the Princess,
And my two daughters I give equal portions
From my revenue; but if my fair wife
Prove, and produce a male-child, him I make
My universal heir, but if a female,
Her dower is with the rest proportionable.
The next I give, it is my soul to heaven,
Where my creator reigns: my words thus end,
Body to earth, my soul to heaven ascend.

div.stage: Enter the Queen, Katherine, the Princess, and the other lady.

sp.speaker: Princess.
sp.l: Stay.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: Hold

sp.speaker: Kath.
sp.l: Executioner forbear.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: Hear me a daughter for a father plead.

sp.speaker: Princess.
sp.l: O father, hear me for my husband's life,
Doubly allied, I am his niece and wife.

sp.speaker: Kath.
sp.l: O father hear me, for a father crave.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: Than sentence him o let me perish rather;
I plead for him that's both my son and father.

sp.speaker: Kath.
sp.l: O make your mercy to this prisoner free.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: Father to us.

sp.speaker: Princess.
sp.l: And husband unto me.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Hence with these womanish clamours.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.l: Unto these
Let me my liege presume to add another,
Behold him kneel that is your son and brother.

sp.speaker: Kath.
sp.l: Your sister and your daughter great King hear.

sp.speaker: Princess.
sp.l: Your mother and your daughter.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: Or like dear,
Your Queen and sister.

sp.speaker: Princess.
sp.l: Speak, what hath he done?

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.l: Whoever saw a father on a son
Give sentence? or my royal lord, which rather
Adds to your guilt, a son condemn the father?

sp.speaker: Chest.
sp.l: My liege, command them hence, they but disturb
The traitor in his death.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: A traitor's he
That dares so term him, Chester, we mean thee:
Our best of subjects, with our height of grace
We wed thee to us, in this strict embrace
Thy virtues, bounties, envied courtesies;
Thy courage, and thy constancy in death,
Thy love and loyalty to the end continued,
More than their clamorous importunities
Prevail with us: then as our best and greatest,
Not to exceed, but equal thee in love,
To end between us this heroic strife,
Accept what we most precious hold, thy life.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Which as your gift I'll keep, till heaven and nature
Confine it hence, and always it expose
unto your love and service; I never loved it,
But since 'twas yours, and by your gift now mine.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: I observe in thee
The substance of all perfect loyalty;
In you save flattery, envy, hate, and pride
Nothing, or ought to goodness that's allied;
Resign those places that belong to him,
Better than so born noble, be unborn.
Till you your hearts can fashion to your faces,
We here suspend you from your styles and places.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.l: A royal doom.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Once more from us receive
Thy beauteous bride, as we will hand our Queen:
The prince already is possessed of his.
Nay Bonvile, as your bridals were together,
So follow in your rank, and by the style
Of a lord baron, you are now no less
If you dare take our word: our funerals thus
We'll turn to feasting, and our blood to wines
Of most choice taste pressed, from the purest grape.
Our noble marshal, kinsman, and our friend,
In our two virtues after times shall sing,
A loyal subject, and a royal King.

div.head: The epilogue to the reader.
div.l: That this play's old, 'tis true, but now if any
Should for that cause despise it, we have many
Reasons, both just and pregnant, to maintain
Antiquity, and those too, not all vain.
We know (And not long since) there was a time,
Strong lines were not looked after, but if rhyme,
O then 'twas excellent: who but believes,
But doublets with stuffed bellies and big sleeves,
And those trunk-hose, which now the age doth scorn,
Were all in fashion, and with frequence worn;
And what's now out of date, who is't can tell,
But it may come in fashion, and suit well?
With rigour therefore judge not, but with reason,
Since what you read was fitted to that season.

div.head: Textual Notes
div.p: The textual notes below aim at making textual corrections readable in their immediate context and facilitating access to the source text. A five-dit number preceded by 'A' or 'B' represents an EEBO-TCP filenumber. A notation like "6-b-2890" means "look for EEBO page image 6 of that text, word 289 on the right side of the double-page image." That reference is followed by the corrupt reading. A black dot stands for an unidentified letter, a black square for an unidentified punctuation mark, a diamond for a missing word, and the ellipsis for a short span of undefined length. The corrected reading is displayed as a kewyord in context.
